event_summary: Student Invited Biological Division Seminar Series
event_description: Surviving the Elements: Harnessing Great Salt Lake Microorganisms for Natural Product DiscoveryNatural products are specialized small molecules that display remarkable chemical diversity, drive key biological processes, and form the basis of many important medicines. Research in the Winter lab explores how bacteria and fungi produce these molecules, with goals of isolating bioactive compounds, uncovering their biosynthetic pathways, and understanding their ecological roles. Microorganisms from extreme environments are particularly promising for drug discovery, as they often encode novel chemistry. Our current work focuses on the completely underexplored hypersaline microbes of Utah’s Great Salt Lake, an environment with salinities five to ten times that of seawater and elevated levels of toxic heavy metals. I will highlight our genomic and chemical approaches to identify biologically active compounds, as well as emerging insithgts into microbial adaptations, biosynthetic novelty, and environmental applications.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences

event_summary: Abraham Clearfield Student Invited Seminar in Inorganic Chemistry
event_description: Engaging 4f-orbitals in the Chemistry of the Rare Earths for Fun and ProfitThe role of the partially filled 4f shell in metal complexes of the rare earths is typically considered to be non-bonding. Further, the degenerate set of 4f electrons confers unique, atomistic electronic- and magnetic-properties to complexes of the elements. In recent years, my research group has been working to expand the capabilities of lanthanide elements through fundamental studies of such complexes and their electronic structures. We have demonstrated that studies of cerium complexes, in terms of electronic structure, properties, and reactivity, are fruitful for discovery of both fundamental aspects of f-element chemistry and new reactivity modalities based on 4f-orbital participation. Recent results will be presented on our studies of organometallic complexes of cerium(IV) and related tetravalent metals showing unique participation of 4f-orbitals in bonding and reactivity, detected by monitoring an unusual single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformation. We have posited that 4f-orbital engagement can also alter reactivity of lanthanide complexes with properly designed ligand frameworks and reaction manifolds through excited states. Our efforts toward these goals, for the purposes of selective, inter-rare earth reactive separations, will also be discussed.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_summary: Organic Division Seminar Series
event_description: Chemical and Biocatalytic Synthesis of Amino-Acid Derived Natural ProductsAmino acid-derived natural products are ubiquitous in nature and commonly possess therapeutic properties. In this presentation, the chemical and biocatalytic syntheses of amino acid-derived natural products will be discussed. First, a chemoenzymatic synthesis of 13-oxoverruculogen, an anticancer endoperoxide, is achieved using enzymatic C-H peroxidation and transition metal catalyzed C-C bond activation reactions. Central to the synthesis involves the use of a substrate analog for enzymatic endoperoxidation to accomplish the synthesis of 13-oxoverruculogen. The second part of this presentation describes the chemical synthesis of ribosomally-synthesized and post-translationally modified peptides (RiPPs). Enteropeptin A is an antimicrobial RiPP natural product with undefined stereochemical configuration at its thioaminoketal stereocenter. The total synthesis of this compound and its congeners resulted in their structural elucidation and the determination of the stereochemical configuration of the enteropeptins.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_summary: Physical Division Seminar Series
event_description: Phase Space Approaches to Electronic Structure: A New Paradigm For Magnetic Field Effects, Chiral Induced Spin Selectivity and Vibrational Circular DichroismThe Born-Oppenheimer (BO) approximation is the cornerstone of chemistry, defining electronic structure relative to fixed nuclear coordinates. It relies on the large mass difference between electrons and nuclei, with nuclei moving much slower and appearing effectively frozen on the time scale of electronic fluctuations. Nevertheless, the BO approximation frequently breaks down, quite famously in photochemistry and/or electron transfer. Less well known is that even when a classical BO theory does not conserve momentum (linear or angular) even when no obvious breakdown occurs. In this talk, I will discuss this failure, introduce phase space approximations as a means to restore conservation, and propose a new paradigm for understanding how nuclear entanglement with electronic degrees of freedom may lead to chiral induced spin selectivity and other magnetic field effects.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences

event_title: Cody Ross Pitts, University of California - Davis
event_summary: Organic Division Seminar Series
event_description: Strain-Release Pentafluorosulfanylation: Strange Molecules Doing Stranger ThingsThis presentation details recent progress in our laboratory toward the synthesis and evaluation of historically underemployed fluorinated functional groups that have been made more accessible using the TCICA/KF approach to oxidative fluorination. A major theme will be our recent merging of SF5 radical chemistry with strain-release functionalization of [1.1.1]propellane, [1.1.0]bicyclobutanes, and [1.1.0]azabicyclobutanes. Structural consequences of making these SF5-based “hybrid bioisosteres” and preliminary mechanistic insight will be discussed. Aside from being a topic of fundamental interest, we believe this work affords an unusual and subtle type of flexibility in molecular design that could prove useful in increasing availability of building blocks containing C(sp3)–SF5 and heteroatom–SF5 bonds to medicinal chemists, agrochemists, and in the materials community.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_summary: Physical Division Seminar Series
event_description: Towards Non-blinking and Photostable Perovskite Quantum Light SourcesPerovskite quantum dots (QDs) are highly valued as single-photon sources because of their unique bright exciton ground state and simple synthesis. So far, the limited photostability of individual perovskite QDs remains a challenge for their use in quantum light sources, despite improvements in increasing the binding strength of surface ligands. Here, we show that crystallized, solid-state ligands with strong intermolecular interactions can achieve near-epitaxial passivation and greatly reduce the surface energy of perovskite QDs. Individual CsPbBr3 QDs embedded in molecular crystals demonstrate nearly non-blinking single-photon emission with a purity of 98%. Moreover, these QDs stay stable after 12 hours of continuous operation and continue to show almost non-blinking behavior under saturated excitation levels. The remarkable stability of individual QDs, combined with precise control during synthesis, allows for detailed studies of their structural and optical properties.
event_category: general interest, speakers, forums, and conferences

event_title: Aaron Tondreau, Los Alamos National Laboratory
event_summary: Inorganic Seminar Series
event_description: The Soft Side of Gallium: Mild Methods of Metal OxidationGallium(III) chloride (GaCl3) has proven effective for the oxidation of lanthanide (Ln) and actinide (An) metals, which offers a mild anhydrous metallurgical processing technology. We have explored the cDhemistry between GaCl3 and many of the f-block elements to explore the useability of this reactivity in applications such as element separations. Additional reactivity of (Ln/An)-gallate products has been pursued, and characterization of the products has been achieved. The results arising from reactions in various carrier matrices, as well as comparisons between products from lanthanide and actinide reactivity will be presented. The differences in physical properties dependent on metal identity that affect the kinetics of reactivity will be presented along with product characterization and potential future applications of this chemistry

event_summary: Organic Division Seminar Series
event_description: Radical-Triggered Functional Group Translocation and Total Synthesis of Talaromyolide DWithin the realm of precise chemoselective manipulations, site-selective functional group translocation via C–H functionalization presents an exciting opportunity to unlock noncanonical synthetic disconnections. I will highlight the development of a novel radical-triggered annulative alkene transposition cascade that enables the modular preparation of valuable spirocyclic ethers from simple starting materials. In the second part, I will discuss our synthetic strategy toward the highly oxidized and bioactive meroterpenoid natural product, talaromyolide D. Our approach leverages efficient C–H disconnection logic to elaborate the polycyclic core of the target, along with several highly diastereoselective transformations, including an electrocatalytic sp²–sp³ cross-coupling.

event_summary: Martin Kronbichler (Rhur-Universität Bochum)Title: High-Performance Simulations of Fluid Flows with High-OrderFinite Element Methods
event_description: Abstract: In my talk, I will present contributions to efficient solvers forincompressible fluid flow in the transitional and turbulent regime. Timeintegration is done by projection methods based on the BDF family. Forthe spatial discretization, high-order H(div) conforming anddiscontinuous Galerkin schemes are used. To render high polynomialdegrees efficient, we use matrix-free evaluation of discrete operators.This setup goes against common practice in PDE software design becausethe implementation of finite element components must be integrated intothe linear solvers, rather than outsourcing all linear algebra toexternal packages. I will present the design in the generic librarydeal.II, which requires the application code to only provide animplementation of the operation in quadrature points of cell and faceintegrals. All the integration as well as loop over the mesh can beprovided by the library, including the MPI ghost communication andparallelization strategies. I will present performance results andaccuracy of Raviart-Thomas elements for velocity in the theNavier-Stokes equations with multigrid solvers for the pressure Poissonequation, comparing the results to our previous work on discontinuousGalerkin methods.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, bryan-college station

event_title: Working Seminar on Banach and Metric Spaces
event_description: Speaker:Florent BaudierTitle:The coarse-Lipschitz structure of subspaces and quotients of classical sequence spaces after N. J. Kalton (Part I)Abstract:In a series of talks, I will discuss parts of the paper “Uniform homeomorphisms of Banach spaces and asymptotic structure” by Nigel Kalton, which appeared posthumously in 2013 in Trans. Amer. Math. Soc.. This amazingly deep paper still contains the most advanced results on the preservation of asymptotic uniform convexity under coarse-Lipschitz embeddings.The topics that will be discussed in the series are:-the preservation under coarse-Lipschitz embeddings of a natural quantitative lower bound on the fundamental function of spreading models generated by weakly null sequences. This result is a consequence of a more general result that establishes a very fine and delicate relationship between certain averages in the Banach space and its modulus of asymptotic midpoint uniform convexity.-understanding conditions under which the weak $p$-co-Banach-Saks property (a sequential property) implies $p$-asymptotic uniform convexity (a tree property). Such a condition relies on the notion of a random $L_p$-norm.-the coarse-Lipschitz rigidity of subspaces and quotients of $\ell_p$, for $p \in (1,\infty)$.-the uniqueness of the coarse (or uniform) structure of $(\sum_{n=1}^\infty \ell_r^n)_{\ell_p}$ for $1<p<r\le 2$ or $2\le r<p<\infty$.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Speaker: Nitin Saxena (IIT Kanpur)Title: Computing Igusa’s local zeta function of univariates in deterministic polynomial-time
event_description: Abstract: Igusa’s local zeta function Z_{f,p}(s) is the generating function that counts the number of integral roots, N_k(f), of f(x_1,…,x_n) mod p^k, for all k. It is a famous result, in analytic number theory, that Z_{f,p} is a rational function in Q(p^s). We give an elementary proof of this fact for a univariate polynomial f(x_1).Our proof, when combined with a fast root-counting algorithm of (Dwivedi, Mittal, Saxena, CCC, 2019), yields the *first* poly(|f|, log p) time algorithm to compute Z_{f,p}(s). We leave the same question for n=2 open.The talk is based on the joint work with Ashish Dwivedi, published in “14th Biannual Algorithmic Number Theory Symposium”, ANTS-XIV <https://www.math.auckland.ac.nz/%7Esgal018/ANTS/>, 2020. Additionally, I will motivate the earlier methods, the follow-up results, and state the major open questions, in the polynomial arithmetic modulo prime-powers.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, bryan-college station

event_summary: Speaker: Yen-Tsung Chen (Penn State University)Title: On special values of Drinfeld modular forms at CM points
event_description: Abstract: Let f be a holomorphic modular form of positive weight k>0 for a congruence subgroup, and z be a CM point on the complex upper half plane. It was proved by Shimura that if f has algebraic Fourier coefficients, then there is a non-zero complex number w so that the ratio f(z)/w^k is an algebraic number. Moreover, w is a non-zero period of a CM elliptic curve defined over a number field whose endomorphism algebra is isomorphic to Q(z). In this talk, we will present an analogue of Shimura’s result for Drinfeld modular forms of arbitrary rank. This generalizes the prior results established by Chang in the rank 2 setting. This is joint work with Oguz Gezmis.

event_title: Sociology Colloquium: “More Than Words: Identity and the Dissemination of Information”
event_summary: The Sociology Department invites you to our Colloquium talk byDr. Alexander Hernandez and Dr. Mary Campbell from Texas A&M University.
event_description: AbstractWe like to think we judge information on its merit.But do we?This research explores the powerful, often unconscious, biases we hold. We experimentally tested whether a speaker’s skin color or accent had a greater effect on how audiences comprehended and trusted scientific information. The findings reveal a clear and significant winner.Come to the colloquium to discover which matters more and what we can do about it.Authors BiosDr. Alexander Hernandezis an Instructional Associate Professor whose work explores the intersection of technology and pedagogy. With a career dedicated to understanding how technology shapes the workplace experience, Dr. Hernandez brings a unique perspective on the ways digital tools influence learning, labor, and professional life. His research and teaching highlight how technological change redefines both classrooms and workplaces, offering insights for educators, students, and professionals navigating today’s evolving environments.Dr. Mary Campbellis Director of theTexas Federal Statistical Research Data Center. Professor Campbell’s research focuses on the measurement of race and ethnicity in surveys and inequality between and within racial and ethnic groups. She is currently working on projects that examine the predictors of racial and ethnic identification change over the life course, and projects that explore the multiple dimensions of racialized experience, such as phenotype and accent.Zoom LinkRSVP Link
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Sociology Colloquium: “Toward Theory Consolidation: Stratification, Organizational, and Political-Legal Effects on Greenhouse Gas Emission”
event_summary: The Sociology Department invites you to our Colloquium talk byDr. Harland Prechel from Texas A&M University.
event_description: Author BioHarland Prechelearned his PhD from the University of Kansas and is Professor of Sociology and Liberal Arts Cornerstone Fellow at Texas A&M University. He works at the intersection of corporations, economic sociology, political sociology, and the environment. His work focuses on how corporations mobilize politically, especially during periods of economic instability and crisis, to transform the political-legal arrangement in which they are embedded. His latest book, Normalized Financial Wrongdoing: How Re-regulating Markets Created Risk, and Increased Inequality, Stanford University Press, examines financialization of the corporation and the economy and financial malfeasance. His research won awards from the Midwest Sociological Society, American Sociological Association, Academy of Management, and the American Society of Criminology.AbstractThe purpose of this research is to understand the relationship between dimensions of the social structure and greenhouse gas emissions in U.S. fossil fueled electrical power plants. While environmental scholars have made important contributions to understanding society-environmental relations, theoretical growth and therefore the capacity to affect environmental policy is hampered by the lack of integration among different middle range perspectives. To address this issue, we adopt Robert Merton’s observation that theoretical advances require the ‘consolidation of groups of special [middle range] theories.’ We develop a conceptual framework and conduct an empirical analysis that includes core dimensions of the component parts of the social structure. We present graphs with predicted values from our regression model to illustrate the expected gas emissions, based on values of key independent variables, making complex statistical results more interpretable and meaningful.Zoom LinkRSVP Link
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Dr. Stephanie Potochnik from the University of North Carolina at Charlottewill present her study on health care access among children in Latinx families across U.S. destinations.
event_description: SeminarHealth care access among children in Latinx families across U.S. destinationsDr. Stephanie Potochnik, The University of North Carolina at CharlotteDate:October 23, 2025 (Thursday)Time:12:00–1:00pm(Lunch will be provided)Location:Texas Research Data Center (TXRDC) at theTeague Research Center Building, Room 326Parking:Central Campus Parking Garage(CCG) (Parking validation available)RSVP formAbstractLatinx children now live in a wider array of U.S. geographic areas than in the past, including both established and new areas of Latinx settlement. This geographic heterogeneity could be consequential for Latinx children’s health care access, with prior research suggesting increased health access barriers for Latinx children in new versus established areas of settlement. Merging public-use county-level data with restricted individual-level health data from the National Health Interview Survey (2010–2014), we quantitatively examine how three health access indicators—health insurance coverage, delayed care, and usual place of care—differ among children (ages 4–17) in Latinx immigrant, Latinx U.S.-born, White U.S.-born, and Black U.S.-born families (n=89,994) across established, fast-growing hub, new, and minor Latinx destination counties. We also examine the potential roles of local immigrant hostilities and health care resources in contributing to health access differences across destinations. In fully adjusted models, children in new destinations are less likely to have health insurance than peers in established destinations, and this disparity is even wider for Latinx children of immigrants. Adjusted model results also show that children in new destinations are more likely to have delayed care than those in established destinations, and children in these four groups in new destinations, fast-growing hubs, and minor destinations are more likely to have no usual place of care than peers in established destinations. Our results are consistent with prior work suggesting that more health care access barriers exist for children, particularly Latinx children of immigrants, in new versus established Latinx destinations.BioDr. Potochnick’s research examines the social demography of immigration and how programs and policies can promote the education and health of immigrant youth. She uses an interdisciplinary perceptive to identify the health and educational needs and resources of immigrant children and families, and to examine the impact national, state, and local-level policies have on their well-being. Current projects examine how federal immigration raids and local-level immigration enforcement policies affect the mental health and school investment decisions of immigrant children at different times in their educational pathway, how pre-migration schooling and parental resources affect children’s post-migration mobility, and how settlement in new immigrant growth areas affects the health of immigrant children.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Tenure-track assistant professor in the Department of Biostatistics at MD Anderson Cancer Center
event_description: Statistical methods for detecting spatially regulated genes in spatial transcriptomicsSpatial transcriptomics (ST) comprises a suite of genomic technologies enabling the profiling of gene expression on tissues with spatial localization information, offering critical insights into how cellular context and the local environment shape transcriptional programs. However, most current methods lack the ability to detect cell-type-specific spatial patterns or model interactions between cell types and their microenvironment. In this talk, I’ll first introduce CELINA, a statistical method for systematically detecting cell type-specific SVGs (ct-SVGs), a subset of SVGs exhibiting distinct spatial expression patterns within specific cell types. Celina utilizes a spatially varying coefficient model to accurately capture each gene’s spatial expression pattern in relation to the distribution of cell types across tissue locations, ensuring effective type I error control and high power. CELINA reveals fine-scale heterogeneity within cell types, providing a clearer view of localized expression changes that is often missed by global analyses. If time allows, I’ll also introduce CYGNET, which detects differentially expressed genes whose expression is modulated by interactions between specific cell types and their local microenvironmental exposures. By explicitly modeling these interactions, CYGNET enhances interpretability and reveals disease mechanisms underlying immune regulation, tumor-stroma crosstalk, and neuroinflammation. Together, CELINA and CYGNET address key limitations in current spatial transcriptomic data analyses, providing a deeper understanding of the spatial gene regulatory mechanisms underlying disease progression and tissue function.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Professor of Biostatistics at the University of Michigan
event_description: Leveraging Causal Inference and Reinforcement Learning to Optimize Personalized Dynamic Treatment RegimesIn this talk, we will present recent advancements in statistical causal learning for evaluating Dynamic Treatment Regimes (DTRs), which allow treatments to be tailored dynamically based on evolving, subject-level data. Identifying an optimal DTR is crucial for advancing precision medicine and personalized healthcare. We first introduce a Tree-based doubly robust Reinforcement Learning (T-RL) method, which builds decision trees while retaining the strengths of batch-mode reinforcement learning. We then present a Stochastic-Tree search method, ST-RL, for evaluating optimal DTRs. ST-RL stands out in the literature due to its non-greedy policy search, and demonstrates superior performance even when handling datasets with a large number of covariates. Furthermore, we address a common challenge in real-world applications: practical constraints or “restrictions” on treatment decisions. To overcome this, we extend to a Restricted Tree-based Reinforcement Learning (RT-RL) method, which incorporates these restrictions into the learning process. Finally, we illustrate the application of these methods using an observational dataset to estimate a two-stage stepped-up DTR for guiding care placement decisions for adolescents with substance use disorders. Through these developments, we aim to showcase how causal learning and reinforcement learning can significantly improve the design of personalized, adaptive treatment strategies in healthcare.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: Facilitator: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription: This workshop helps participants enhance their teaching and public speaking skills through microteaching demonstrations delivered in a low-risk environment. Each participant delivers a 5-minute presentation, receiving constructive feedback from a consultant and an undergraduate student on pronunciation, presentation structure, visual aids, nonverbal communication and more.By presenting in front of a friendly audience, participants develop confidence, and by observing peers’ presentations, they gain additional insight into best practices for comprehensible and well-developed presentations.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…1) Construct and deliver short, well-structured and intelligible presentations.2) Create a visual aid to support key points.3) Identify areas for improvement in their own presentations and those of their peers.Register here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/8325

event_title: Conversation Circle for English Language Proficiency
event_summary: Facilitator: Sarah Vargas, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Conversation Circle is a supportive space for practicing spoken English through group discussions on cultural topics, including American university culture. Participants improve spontaneous speaking, active listening, and conversational turn-taking.Through communication with speakers from a variety backgrounds, they acclimate to different accents. The sessions promote social connections, intercultural dialogue, and a sense of belonging. The goal is to enhance English fluency, comprehension, and confidence.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able too…1) Employ effective spontaneous communication skills in social, academic and professional settings.2) Elaborate on their viewpoints and opinions in group discussions.3) Construct clear and well-structured responses during impromptu conversations.4) Apply appropriate turn-taking and active listening techniques in casual group discussions and more formal academic discussions.Register here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/7534

event_title: Academic English Communication Skills: Office Hours (Part 2)
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/8335Facilitator:Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Many teaching assistants have the important responsibility of conducting office hours, in which students bring a range of questions and concerns. The second in our two-part workshop series on communication skills for office hours, this workshop provides attendees the opportunity to role-play with undergraduate students. Participants will practice initiating, managing, and concluding office hour interactions, while gaining insight into student perspectives. For international instructors.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Conduct effective office hours that meet undergraduate expectations and address a variety of student concerns with confidence and professionalism.2. Structure office hour sessions effectively, incorporating appropriate opening, discussion, and closing strategies to meet the goals of the session.3. Employ empathetic and active listening and manage challenging interactions with students.4. Choose appropriate external resources for student referrals.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

event_summary: Facilitator: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription: This four-session pronunciation workshop systematically explores the vocal tract and segments of speech that make meaningful differences in North American English. Through a variety of activities and handouts, attendees will become familiar with each consonant sound and with resources to practice listening discrimination and accurate pronunciation on their own.They each have the opportunity to get personalized feedback on their own pronunciation.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…1) Distinguish consonant sounds from consonant letters2) When listening, discern voiced consonants from voiceless consonants, and discern the different manners of articulation (stop, fricative, affricate, approxmant, and nasal)3) When speaking, shift between voiced and voiceless at will; produce consonants with different manners of articulation and different places of articulation4) Identify one digital resource to use for ongoing pronunciation developmentRegister here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10677
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

Each participant delivers a 5-minute presentation, receiving constructive feedback from a consultant and an undergraduate student on pronunciation, presentation structure, visual aids, nonverbal communication and more. By presenting in front of a friendly audience, participants develop confidence, and by observing peers’ presentations, they gain additional insight into best practices for comprehensible and well-developed presentations.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able too…1) Construct and deliver short, well-structured and intelligible presentations.2) Create a visual aid to support key points.3) Identify areas for improvement in their own presentations and those of their peers.Register here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/8325

event_title: Explaining Procedures and Policies: Practicing the Passive Voice (English Language Proficiency)
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11310Facilitator:Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. In academic settings, the passive voice is often used to explain procedures, report actions, and emphasize outcomes rather than agents. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice the passive voice in realistic teaching scenarios, such as clarifying policies and describing classroom and laboratory processes. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Identify common teaching contexts in which the passive voice is preferred for clarity, formality, or focus.2. Accurately produce the passive voice when explaining procedures, policies, and processes.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: ELP Journal Club: A Conversation Circle for Text-Based Discussions
event_summary: Facilitator: Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Journal Club is designed for international TAs and faculty to gain confidence in reading aloud and leading and participating in classroom discussions about texts. Each week, participants will receive a short article two days ahead of time to prepare for our discussions.This workshop will focus on improving pronunciation, expanding vocabulary, and developing effective discussion strategies. Participants will also have the opportunity to lead discussions, enhancing their confidence and skills in academic settings.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…1) Read aloud with comprehensible pronunciation and increased confidence.2) Use key terms from academic texts accurately in discussions.3) Effectively facilitate group discussions about various texts.4) Employ turn-taking skills when participating in discussions.Register here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10889

event_title: English Language Proficiency Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 5): Prominent Words and Discourse Cues
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11318Facilitator:Ginessa PayneDescription:Fifth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop teaches the intonation that speakers need in order to convey their intended message, with well-placed emphasis. Discourse cues (transition signals) are introduced as tools that help the audience follow the speaker’s logic.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Distinguish content words (meaningful words) from function words (grammatical words).2. Pronounce the prominent word within a phrase with the appropriate pitch, volume, length, and vowel quality.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: English Language Proficiency Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 6): Asking Questions and Active Learning
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11321Facilitator:Ginessa PayneDescription:Sixth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop introduces Bloom’s Taxonomy and the “flipped classroom” approach where active learning takes place during class time. It encourages teachers to ask their students thought-provoking questions that are grammatically correct and pronounced with correct intonation.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Distinguish lower-order thinking from higher-order thinking.2. Generate questions appropriate for college students.3. Pronounce wh- questions and yes/no questions with accurate grammar and appropriate intonation contours.

event_title: Don’t Tense Up about Verb Tenses: Choosing the Right Tense to Communicate Effectively (English Language Proficiency)
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10387Facilitator:Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate more effectively when they utilize the appropriate verb tense. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice narrative verb tenses while discussing research and reviewing previously covered classroom topics. They’ll explore the pedagogical impact of reviewing prior learning. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Utilize narrative tenses to recall previous lecture material and discuss connections to current content.2. Produce narrative verb tenses effectively in the discussion of research findings, choosing the appropriate tense to convey temporal relationships.3. Facilitate review activities during lab sessions or lectures, utilizing appropriate narrative tenses to reiterate and reinforce key concepts covered in previous classes.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: English Language Proficiency Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 7): Answering Questions and Contrastive Stress
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11322Facilitator:Ginessa PayneDescription:Seventh in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop equips teachers and presenters to respond to unexpected questions from an audience. It teaches the intonation that speakers need in order to make a point, with well-placed emphasis on contrasting words.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Use a four-step process for fielding questions.2. Pronounce contrasting words with pitch, volume, duration, and vowel quality that set them apart from other words.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: Live Workshop in the Virtual Language Lab for English Proficiency
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/9373Facilitator:Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Develop your pronunciation and listening skills at your own pace and from the comfort of your own home using the free CTE-ELP Virtual Language Lab in Canvas. Graduate students, undergraduate students, faculty, staff, visiting scholars, and post-docs who speak English as a Second Language (ESL) are invited to this live interactive workshop. Participants will walk through a variety of exercises in the VLL to get familiar with it and get their questions answered.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Log in to the VLL in the Canvas LMS.2. Activate voice typing to receive machine feedback.3. Respond to a variety of quiz questions 4. By the end of the session, be able to use the VLL independently.
event_category: international students, training workshops, students

event_summary: Facilitator: Ginessa Payne, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:The vowel sounds of American English are challenging to learners of English because there are so many, and because English spelling does not convey the pronunciation predictably. This four-session series of interactive workshops aims to increase attendees’ phonological awareness, and as a result, their listening and intelligibility.Through a variety of activities and handouts, attendees will become familiar with each vowel and with resources to practice listening discrimination and pronunciation on their own. Each attendee has the opportunity to get personalized feedback on their own pronunciation.Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to…1) Distinguish vowel sounds from vowel letters2) When speaking, control lip rounding and spreading; control height of tongue and openness of jaw3) When listening, distinguish similar vowel sounds from one another4) Use bodily-kinesthetic techniques to gain conscious control of the vocal tract5) Reduce a vowel in an unstressed syllable to schwa6) Identify one digital resource to use for ongoing pronunciation developmentRegister here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10678
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: Suggestion or Requirement? Use the Right Modal Verb to Give Clear Instructions (English Language Proficiency)
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10388Facilitator:Michele Vick, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate more effectively when they utilize the appropriate modal verbs (such as should, might, must) to convey obligations and suggestions. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice modal verbs in the context of giving instructions and corrective feedback. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Employ modal verbs (such as should and have to) in the feedback process, conveying constructive criticism and suggestions using appropriate modals.2. Plan and communicate clear and unambiguous instructions using appropriate modal verbs to convey obligations, recommendations, and suggestions effectively.
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: English Language Proficiency Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 8): Linking Words and Leading a Discussion
event_summary: Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/event/11323Facilitator:Ginessa PayneDescription:Eighth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop teaches the value of a well-managed class discussion and provides functional language for leading such a discussion. It also introduces a critical aspect of pronunciation, which is the linking of one word to the next.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. In a class discussion, react and respond appropriately to keep the discussion advancing.2. Pronounce phrases with connected speech (linking consonant to consonant, linking consonant to vowel, and linking vowel to vowel across word boundaries).
event_category: international students, training workshops, faculty, staff

event_title: University Libraries presents: Data Science & Collaboration with Google Colab
event_summary: A big component of data science – analysis, sharing, etc. – involves collaboration. Utilizing Google Apps and Jupyter Notebook, an open-source interactive computing platform, Google Colab can support the collaboration and sharing of data for projects. Learn what Google Colab is, how to use Google Colab for interactive computation, and suggestions for keeping your data safe in Colab.Audience:This intermediate workshop is geared towards students, faculty, and staff looking for a free, low barrier to entry way of collaborating with others in data analysis. Some experience with Jupyter Notebook, as well as basic knowledge of Python, is helpful.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, students

Using the CTE’s active learning guide, this session will provide easy-to-implement techniques to make your teaching more interactive, inclusive, and effective—no matter the subject or class size.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Define active learning and explain its benefits in higher education settings.2. Identify at least three active learning strategies appropriate for different classroom formats (lecture, discussion, lab, etc.).3. Design a brief activity or lesson segment using an active learning strategy aligned with their course goals.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=45076Actively participating in this event and completing the reflection in Canvas is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.Visitgrad-aggies.tamu.eduto join.

event_title: Career Center presents: Graduate Students Networking at a Conference
event_summary: Virtual
event_description: Attending conferences is often a large part of the graduate student experience, but many students wonder how to best leverage networking practices while attending. This workshop provides information on how to effectively network at scholarly and professional conferences.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to identify the people they want to talk to• How to most effectively use networking time a conferences• The finer parts of small talk and how to have more in-depth conversations with attendees• Best practices with sending a pre-meeting email• Navigating a virtual conference• Crafting an introduction that will hold people’s attentionAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Career Center presents: Graduate Students Construction Management Resumes
event_summary: VirtualOnline only
event_description: Graduate students looking to enter construction management have a unique skillset that needs to be best highlighted to hiring authorities. This presentation addresses how to craft a compelling construction management resume for both master’s and doctoral students. Both early-career and mid-career resumes are highlighted.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to design a resume so recruiters and hiring managers can easily find information to increase the likelihood of getting called for a screening call• How to highlight experiences and knowledge related to estimation, BIM, vendor and trade management, specialty knowledge (e.g., HVAC, LEED), Primavera, etc.• How to discuss the scope of construction projects. Attending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.Attending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students

event_title: Center for Teaching Excellence presents: Accessible PDF (GSPDT)
event_summary: Facilitators:Carlos Perez, Center for Teaching ExcellenceDescription:The recent Title II revision (the Final Rule) mandates that all digital content meet accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users. Part of the Digital Accessibility Series, this session focuses on PDF files. PDF files can be among the most challenging to remediate. In this session, we will address the common challenges associated with PDF remediation. The workshop will explore typical accessibility issues found in PDF files. Participants will have the opportunity to use Adobe Acrobat’s built-in accessibility checker and practice with this tool.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Identify common accessibility issues with PDF files.2. Discuss some limitations to remediation of PDF files.3. Evaluate the accessibility of PDF files using Adobe Acrobat built-in accessibility checker.Register Here:https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?scheduleid=45074Actively participating in this event and completing the reflection in Canvas is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.Visitgrad-aggies.tamu.eduto join.

event_summary: Attendees will learn the principles of data management by playing some real data samples and:Analyzing a publicly available data set.Attempting to re-create findings of a public data project.And critiquing data curation for a public project.Audience: This workshop is helpful for researchers in any discipline and stage in their career.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Career Center presents: Graduate Student Academic Cover Letters
event_summary: HybridOnline only
event_description: One of the integral pieces of an academic application package for a faculty or post-doctoral role is the cover letter. It’s a document full of nuance that should be aligned with the institution, department/lab, and role. This presentation provides a detailed examination of how to write an effective academic cover letter.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• How to read an academic job posting to identify the important information that should be included in the cover letter• How to write a cover letter for teaching-intensive and research-intensive tenure track faculty roles, non-tenure track faculty roles, and post-doctoral roles.• How to align one’s cover letter with the needs of the department/PI and profile of the institutionAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: University Libraries presents: Refworks: Your Research Superpower
event_summary: Manage the chaos of research like a superhero would. Take advantage of tools like Refworks and before you know it, citation management software will be your superpower too.As you begin your next research paper or project, or while you are working on your current one, take time to get introduced to RefWorks. It is an easy-to-learn yet powerful tool that will help you stay organized and save precious time by streamlining your research process. This workshop is designed to introduce new users to citation management with RefWorks and is open to students, faculty and staff.Register HereAttending and actively participating in this event, and completing its reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Career Center presents: Graduate Students Resilience and Perseverance in Graduate School (Part 1: Foundations of Grit)
event_summary: HybridOnline only
event_description: The demands of graduate education can test emotional endurance, self-motivation, and mental health. This first session in a two-part series explores the science of resilience and perseverance, helping students develop a foundational understanding of what it takes to persist through challenges.Attendees of this workshop will learn:• Definitions and psychological foundations of resilience and perseverance• How adversity impacts motivation, focus, and self-esteem in grad school• Strategies to build mental toughness and a growth mindset• The role of values and purpose in sustaining long-term effortAttending this event and completing the reflection is worth 1 PDU towards a GRAD Aggies Professional Development Certificate for graduate & professional students.

event_title: Center for Teaching Excellence presents: Introduction to Canvas (GSPDT)

event_summary: Navigating difficult conversations is an essential skill in any workplace. This course, developed by HRDQ and Organizational Development, provides participants with the tools and techniques needed to handle challenging discussions effectively.
event_description: Participants will learn to understand the nature of difficult conversations and the seven stages involved in managing them. The course emphasizes the importance of empathy, preparation, and best practices for initiating and delivering conversations. Through interactive activities and real-life scenarios, learners will practice and refine their skills in a safe and supportive environment.This course is designed to:Understand the nature of difficult conversations and what it takes to handle them.Identify the seven stages of handling difficult conversations.Use empathy to minimize negative responses and strengthen relationships.Apply best practices for preparing, initiating, and delivering the conversation.Discover how to generate solutions and bring the conversation to a close.Register via TrainTraqby October 3rd.If the registration deadline has passed or the date for this section doesn’t work for you, please visit theCourse Detailspage and click on the Upcoming Sections tab to explore other available options.

event_title: Common Grounds - Building a Brand That Matters: How Texas A&M is Building a Force for Good
event_summary: The University Staff Council invites staff to join us for “Common Grounds,” a series to connect staff with University Leadership on a variety of topics.
event_description: JoinR. Ethan Braden,Vice President and Chief Marketing and Communications Officer,for an inside look at how Texas A&M is elevating its reputation and impact on the national stage through disciplined brand building. Based on the principles of his signature Keynote presentation,Building a Brand That Matters, discover how the university is translating its core values into bold storytelling, innovative partnerships, and creative expressions that make Texas A&M impossible to overlook. Learn how staff across campus play a vital role in shaping the Aggie story, from the everyday choices we make to the way we share our work with the world. This session will connect you to the vision behind our brand, highlight recent successes, and offer practical ways you can help Texas A&M be recognized not just as the best in the nation, but the bestforit.This will be aone-hour presentation before theUSC Meeting. The series can be attended in person at theGeneral Services Complexin Room 101A orvia Zoom.For nearly two decades,R. Ethan Bradenhas built brands and teams that people love and trust. Today, he serves as Vice President and Chief Marketing and Communications Officer at Texas A&M University, where he and his team are shaping the national narrative around one of America’s most storied and consequential institutions. Ethan leads the effort to position, promote, and protect the largest land-grant university in the nation, elevating Texas A&M’s reputation, relevance, and reach.Prior to Texas A&M, Ethan served as Executive Vice President and Chief Marketing Officer at Purdue University and Purdue Global, where he helped transform Purdue into a nationally recognized marketing powerhouse. Under his leadership, Purdue earned three Fast Company “Brands That Matter” honors and was named #1 in education on Fast Company’s 2023 Most Innovative Companies list, the only university included.A sought-after speaker and thought leader, Ethan has spoken at Salesforce’s Dreamforce and Connections, Adweek’s Brand Week, Google Marketing Live, and keynoted Content Marketing World, where he was named B2C Content Marketer of the Year (2023). He was also named “Marketer of the Year” in higher education by the American Marketing Association (2020), and his work has been featured in Ad Age, The Washington Post, Morning Brew, and NPR, which dubbed him “the top dog in higher ed marketing.”Before entering higher education, Ethan spent nearly a decade at Eli Lilly and Company, leading global marketing efforts for billion-dollar brands including Cymbalta and Jardiance.He holds a BA from Willamette University, an MBA from the University of Notre Dame, and lives in College Station, Texas, with his wife and three children.

event_title: CANCELED: Crucial Conversations for Mastering Dialogue - Day 1
event_summary: Backed by 30 years of social science, “crucial conversations” skills represent the standard in effective communication and the marker of high-performance individuals and organizations. This course will teach you how to engage in those difficult or high-stakes crucial conversations.
event_description: Whenever you’re not getting the results you want, it’s likely an important conversation either hasn’t happened or hasn’t been handled well. In fact, both individual and organizational success are largely determined by how quickly, directly, and effectively we speak up when it matters most. Despite the importance of crucial conversations, we often avoid them because we’re afraid we’ll make matters worse. Mishandled conversations have a huge impact. In fact, they’re at the root of most persistent problems in organizations, teams, and relationships. At the heart of healthy and high-performance organizations are people willing and able to hold crucial conversations.Backed by 30 years of social science, “crucial conversations” skills represent the standard in effective communication and the marker of high-performance individuals and organizations. This course will teach you how to engage in those difficult or high-stakes crucial conversations.This course is designed to:Identify the elements of a crucial conversationDemonstrate and prepare to handle crucial conversations effectivelyRegister via TrainTraq byOctober 23rd.

event_title: New Exhibit: Rocks: Earth’s Majestic Building Blocks
event_description: The Museum proudly announces an exclusive in-house exhibit, Rocks: Earth’s Majestic Building Blocks. Highlighting the Stanley and Sharon Anderson Mineral Collection recently gifted to the Museum, the exhibit will also feature specimens from the Houston Museum of Natural Science, the Texas A&M Department of Geology and Geophysics, artifacts from Watson Signs and Monuments, and others. Learn about the mysteries of Earth’s extraordinary rocks and minerals as you view colorful crystals, ancient stone tools, local fossils, and a magnificent array of rocks from around the world.Opening PresentationFriday, June 6, 6:30 pmStanley “Andy” AndersonProfessional Geologist and CollectorGallery viewing and reception follows.

event_description: Unity Theatre presents The Foreigner, a comedy by Larry Shue playing on the Main Stage October 2 – 19, 2025.When British demolition expert Froggy brings his painfully shy friend Charlie to a Georgia fishing lodge, he claims Charlie is a foreigner who speaks no English—just to spare him from awkward conversations. But Charlie actually understands everything and soon overhears dark secrets, shady plots, and romantic entanglements the others think are safe to share. As the lies unravel, Charlie finds himself in the middle of a wild and hilarious chain of events. Clever, fast-paced, and full of heart, this comedy delivers nonstop laughs and an unexpected triumph for the underdog.

event_title: “George Bush as Grand Strategist: How the Gulf War Mattered to American Statecraft” with Spencer Bakich
event_description: President Bush began his Presidency in unprecedented times. With the Soviet Union collapsing and the Cold War ending, and the Berlin Wall crumbling and Germany preparing to reunify, President Bush was uniquely positioned to fashion a new world strategy for international politics and cooperation. The conflict between Iraq and Kuwait, along with the subsequent invasion, gave President Bush an opportunity to test his leadership and his vision for international collaboration and democratization.In his book, The Gulf War: George H.W. Bush and American Grand Strategy in the Post-Cold War Era (2024), Spencer Bakish discusses President Bush’s transformational politics during Desert Shield/Desert Storm.Spencer Bakich is a Professor of International Studies and the Director of the National Security Program at the Virginia Military Institute, and a Senior Fellow at the University of Virginia’s Miller Center. His scholarly work includes authoring and editing three books, providing commentary to major publications and interviewing senior policymakers, military officers and Foreign Service officers who served with George H.W. Bush.This event is being held as a part of our 35 Anniversary of Desert Shield/Desert Storm series, where we will explore various aspects of the conflict throughout the fall of 2025 and the spring of 2026.Join us on Thursday, October 16, as Spencer Bakich discusses President Bush’s transformational international politics during Desert Shield/Desert Storm. Lunch will be provided and seating is limited, so please register your attendance at Bush41.org/events.
event_category: general interest, listening session, speakers, forums, and conferences

event_description: Join us for the 17th AnnualBuffalo Stampede 5K Race and 1 Mile Fun Run! These live Chrono timed races use disposable bib tags on USATF Certified courses benefitting the Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History. All Sports Timing isconducting the race, and race results will be available at www.allsportstiming.com.REGISTER for our race!NOTE: Online registration will end at 5 pm on October 17, although paper registrations will still be accepted on Race Day, October 18. The following rates apply to the 2025 Buffalo Stampede.Course Details and AmenitiesThe 5K course is gently rolling, scenic, relatively flat, fast, and takes you through open country and past neighborhoods and parks. It has a downhill finish, and offers you a great chance for a PR and a tune-up for other races. Courses are out and back and offer a safe route well marked by Area Wide Protective. Two Cheer Stations will be along the route to encourage runners. The first 2 cheer stations to sign up will be chosen and receive a cash prize! The Course closes at 9am.Celebrity StarterEach year the Museum partners with a local celebrity to kick off the Stampede. Last year, Buffalo Bill paid us a visit, and past starters included Texas A&M Women’s Basketball Coach Gary Blair and Olympic Gold Medalist, Randy Matson. Stay tuned for our surprise announcement later this summer regarding this year’s celebrity starter!Registration & Packet Pick-UpRunners’ packets and late registration will be available on Thursday, October 16, 10:00 am to 5:00 pm and Friday, October 17, 10:00 am to 5:00 pm at the Museum. Packets may also be picked up on race day beginning at 6:00 am. Race Day registrations will be accepted from 6:00-7:00 am, but prior registration is STRONGLY encouraged. Online registration closes October 17 at 5 pm; paper registration is available through race day. Directions to the Museum are available at: www.brazosvalleymuseum.org. Entry fees are non-refundable; NO exceptions.Parking and Race Day AccessThe entrance to the Brazos Center from Briarcrest will be closed. Visitors must enter the Museum’s parking lot from the back of the Target shopping center.Awards and Age DivisionsOverall male and female finishers in the 5K will receive beautiful unique buffalo sculpture trophies. First, second, and third place awards are given in the 5K for each 10-year age group. Age-group awards are buffalo head trophies for first place and custom buffalo medals for second and third places. Age-groups are: 12 and under; 13-19; 20-29; 30-39; 40-49; 50-59; 60-69; 70-79; 80-85; 86+. 5K Race and 1 Mile Fun Run finishers will receive unique finisher medals. Age group awards will not be given in the 1 Mile Fun Run.Awards Ceremony5K Awards will be presented at 9 am (sooner if all runners are in).​Cheer StationFriends and family can create a cheer station to cheer runners on the course!The course will have 2 Cheer Stations (each including at least 4 people); the first 2 stations to sign up will be chosen and receive $150 each.All cheer station participants will receive free T-shirts, snacks, admission to the Museum, as well as enjoy Boonville Days activities, and more!Cheer Station Information Packets with the team’s course location must be picked up at the Museum on Thursday, October 16, or Friday, October 17, from 10:00 am to 5 pm.Official Race PhotosPhotos on the course, at the finish line, and for awards will be taken by Spring Action Photos and may be viewed on their website post-race. Questions? Contact the Spring Action Photos staff at springactionphotos@gmail.com!T-ShirtAll registrants will receive a T-shirt, however sizes and availability are guaranteed by race day only for registration made on or before October 1. You may also purchase an additional race t-shirt for $18 until October 18 as supplies last. You may call to see if we have extras available after that date.​WeatherThe event will be held RAIN or SHINE! If the event is canceled due to dangerous weather, entry fees will NOT be refunded.Course RegulationsNo skateboards, bicycles, devices with wheels, or dogs will be allowed on the course with runners. Parents running or walking with children in strollers are welcome.
event_category: general interest

event_description: A Texas Heritage FestivalSaturday, October 18, 20259 am - 4 pmJoin the Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History on October 18, 2025, for the 20th annual Boonville Days: Texas Heritage Festival!To kick off the festival, runners and walkers of all ages are welcome to join in the 17th Annual Buffalo Stampede 5K Race and 1 Mile Fun Run at 7:30 am starting at the Brazos Center.After the race, the entire family can enjoy other fun activities highlighting Texas History at this free heritage festival!From 9 am - 4 pm learn about Brazos County’s pioneer history: visit with characters in period costume, enjoy cowboys, reenactors, musicians, dancers, artisans, and much more.Visitors will also have the opportunity to observe demonstrations of frontier skills and trades including flint-knapping, spinning, weaving, quilting, and blacksmithing.This is a family-friendly event, so there will be free pony rides, train rides, and other activities for children. The Museum will be open free with more exhibits, activities, and demonstrators inside!This event was made possible in part through Eugene Edge III Charitable Trust, Wakefield Foundation, Twin City Properties, Brazos County Historical Commission, and the Hotel Tax Revenue funded from the City of College Station and the City of Bryan through the Arts Council of Brazos Valley.Museum and ExhibitsIn addition to all the demonstrations of pioneer history and fun children’s games, crafts, and other activities, families can view a variety of live animals, and browse through the Museum’s Discovery Room, library, and exhibition gallery. Visitors can also explore the Museum’s Texas History display and the current special exhibit: Rocks: Earth’s Majestic Building Blocks, on display through October 25.​Boonville Heritage CabinLike historic buildings? Don’t miss a chance to see inside the restored and furnished 19th c. dogtrot cabin, replica buildings of the Boonville Court House, a smokehouse, the Masonic lodge, educational activities, booths, and other re-enactors at Boonville Heritage Park! Learn about the fascinating history of the town of Boonville, the original Brazos County seat.​Staff will be on hand to share stories about the park and the colorful history of the town of Boonville, the original Brazos County seat.​*IMPORTANT Access to Parking at the Park: Shuttle buses from the Museum will be going all day, courtesy of Sterling Auto Group, starting at 10 am, and leaving from the Chuck Wagon Area. There is limited handicapped parking at the Park, and additional parking is available in surrounding public areas.
event_category: general interest

event_title: LWV Speed Dating with the Candidates
event_description: The League of Women Voters of the Brazos Valley will be holding a ‘Speed Dating with the Candidates’ Forum on October 18 at College Station Ringer Library from 1:00-3:00 for the Bryan and College Station School Board Candidates. This format will have the candidates rotate to multiple tables of voters to answer questions. Candidates will change tables every 10 minutes. This format will allow candidates to meet with voters in a small group and answer questions.We are inviting all the Bryan and College Station School Board ISD candidates in contested elections.

event_description: A Halloween celebration for all ages!Join the Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History for an Owl-O-Ween Festival for all ages from 5:30 to 8:00 pm on Friday, October 24, 2025. This spook-tacular event includes educational booths, face painting, crafts, carnival games, and more! Museum admission is free; tickets must be purchased to participate in games, concessions, and the haunted woods tours.​Festival participants will enjoy live animals including: insects and spiders from the TAMU Entomology Graduate Student Organization, snakes and lizards from HERPS Exotic Reptile and Pet Shop, animals from Opossum Town, and other Owl-O-Ween surprises! Don’t miss the chance to view some iconic Halloween animals up close!​Older children will also have a “hoot of a time” on the haunted woods tour in the Carter Creek Nature Trail. Multiple tours will be conducted throughout the evening.​All ages who attend in costume will receive a special goody bag! Visitors are also encouraged to view the Museum’s special exhibit, Steam, Smoke & Steel: Riding the Rails through Time, on display through October 26.​The Brazos Valley Museum of Natural History is open to visitors Tuesday through Saturday from 10 am to 5 pm. Regular admission fees: adults $5; seniors/students/children $4; children 3 and under are free. To learn more about this and other Museum events, activities and exhibitions call 979-776-2195 or follow them on Facebook.
event_category: general interest

event_description: Embrace the Halloween spirit with our Spooky Night Hike at Millican Reserve! This special evening hike, taking place just before Halloween, offers a fun and slightly eerie adventure through the moonlit trails of the Reserve.This guided hike is not haunted, but you’ll experience the thrill of the outdoors at night, with:- Spooky sounds and stories shared along the way- Highlights of nocturnal animals and their night-time behaviors- Hints of Halloween ambiance with lanterns, glow sticks, and the mystery of the woods after darkWhether you’re a fan of fall, nature, or just a good excuse to get outside after hours, this hike is a safe and festive way to enjoy the season. Costumes are welcome but must be trail-appropriate and safe for hiking. Recommended for ages 10 and up.What to Bring:- A refillable water bottleClosed-toe shoes and weather-appropriate clothing- A flashlight or headlamp (red light preferred)Parking:Please use the Farm Entrance to Millican Reserve (19851 FM 2154). Designated parking is available at Basecamp. You MAY NOT PROCEED past the parking area in your vehicle. All outdoor events are subject to cancellation due to inclement weather. Registered attendees will be notified via email in the event of a cancellation.If you have questions, or are having difficulty registering for this event, please email us at info@millicanreserve.com.
event_category: general interest

event_title: Sports Law Society: Breaking In: Resumes, Internships, and Career Paths
event_summary: Sports Law Society: Breaking In: Resumes, Internships, and Career PathsOctober 6, 202512-1pmRoom 201
event_description: The Breaking Into Sports Law Panel will examine the challenges law students face when pursuing careers in one of the most specialized and relationship-driven areas of practice. Unlike traditional fields with structured recruiting pipelines, opportunities in sports law are often based on personal connections and industry-specific experience.Panelists include:- Ted Koehler, Senior Director & Associate General Counsel, PGA of America- Grant Newton, Senior Associate Commissioner & Chief Legal Officer, Conference USA- Alex Campbell, NFL Agent & Founder of AJAX Sports AgencyThe discussion will focus on how students can position themselves for opportunities in sports law through tailored resumes, externships, and practical experiences. Panelists will share advice on identifying the right opportunities, approaching organizations in the industry, and developing the skills that make a candidate stand out in a field without traditional recruiting pipelines.

“Página a Página” is an educational event that fosters cultural awareness and appreciation through literature. MSC CAMAC will provide free books selected by the committee from Hispanic/Latinx authors. This event aims to offer a glimpse into Latinx cultures/experiences and broaden participants’ understanding and appreciation of art and history involving Hispanic and Latinx communities for any student interested.

TEDxTAMU salons are an uniquely interactive TEDx experience where students, faculty, and the community have an opportunity to experience TED in new ways. Comprised of three salons spread throughout the year, TEDxTAMU Salons allow for attendees to build skills from prominent members of the community and past TEDx speakers, engage in lively discussions, and to foster ideas worth spreading. There are three TEDxTAMU Salons, occurring on 10/19/25, 12/02/25, and 01/24/26. During these events, attendees will have a curated experience focused on a specific growth-based topic, such as improving networking abilities, preparing for finals, and learning the ins and outs of giving a TED Talk. These events are led by the members of MSC ALOT, and will vary in schedule for each salon focusing in on different themes.

event_description: The MSC Lost and Found is the centralized lost and found for the Texas A&M campus and is housed inside the MSC Programs office. Once each fall/spring semester, eligible unclaimed items that have been logged into the Lost and Found system for over 90 days are available for purchase at discounted prices. Items are priced and arranged in general categories, including: clothes/shoes, water bottles, jewelry, graphing calculators, headphones/earbuds, and much more! All items are sold “as is” and all sales are final.Payment:Cash preferred; credit/debit cards accepted.Shopping Time Limit:15-minute increments per group (re-entry allowed as space permits)

Mi Casa Es Su Casa is a program that offers students an opportunity to network and create a support system at Texas A&M University. Texas A&M Professors and staff invite current students to their homes for an evening of meaningful conversations over a home cooked meal. This program provides a chance for students to network and gain a better understanding of the various opportunities that could open up in the future. There are also giveaways involved for students when attending the dinners! Sign up today for your chance to win some swag and make meaning connections with other students, faculty, and staff!

event_summary: The Office of Sustainability & Campus Enrichment’s Undergraduate Internship Program applications open today. Learn more at sustainability.tamu.edu.
event_description: The goal of the Office of Sustainability & Campus Enrichment’s Internship Program is to bring undergraduate students from a variety of backgrounds and perspectives together to create a dynamic team that works to create a culture of sustainability at Texas A&M University. Interns work together to increase awareness and education about the three pillars of sustainability: environmental, economic, and social. The team focuses on educating the campus community about topics such as: energy and water use, transportation, food services, construction and built environment, purchasing, recycling, and social sustainability through the development of outreach initiatives and event coordination. Additionally, interns support assessment and planning efforts prioritized by the office.The Internship Program is open to any TAMU undergraduate student and all majors are encouraged to apply because true sustainability must be an interdisciplinary enterprise.Applications are open October 6, 2025 – November 9, 2025 at sustainability.tamu.edu.

event_title: J.L. “Corky” Frank ’58 Graduate Seminar Series: Dr. Carlos Torres-Verdin
event_summary: Join Dr. Carlos Torres-Verdin for the J.L. “Corky” Frank ’58 Seminar Series, where he discusses “Well Placement/Geosteering and Rock/Fluid Imaging with Borehole Ultra-Deep Resistivity Measurements: Developments and Verifications of Multi-Dimensional and Data-Adaptive.”
event_description: Traditional borehole geophysical measurements (e.g., LWD or wireline measurements) have a very shallow range of spatial sensitivity around the well trajectory (shorter than 1-6 ft), hence are limited in their ability to image and/or anticipate reservoir-size features that are critical for well geosteering, and optimal reservoir engineering and in-flow performance. Ultra-Deep Azimuthal Resistivity (UDAR) measurements are relatively new commercial geophysical measurements which provide advanced borehole imaging capabilities (anywhere between 10-150 ft away from the well trajectory) by bridging the gap between well logging and seismic interpretation. However, interpreting UDAR measurements in complex, spatially heterogeneous, or anisotropic formations remains challenging. Traditional 2D and 3D inversion (imaging) procedures are computationally intensive, therefore unsuitable for real-time well geosteering applications.We describe our recent progress in the development of fast modeling and inversion algorithms for UDAR measurements. These algorithms are designed for multi-CPU clusters and tailored for integration with local 3D geological models and arbitrary well trajectories. Modeling employs a finite-volume solution of Maxwell’s equations implemented on an adaptive Lebedev grid, effectively accounting for diverse formation complexities and tool configurations. A new block-based solver computes multi-input multi-output (MIMO) responses efficiently, significantly reducing CPU runtime. Inversion is performed with both gradient-based (Occam-type) and stochastic approaches and incorporates regularization to account for measurement noise and non-uniqueness in the estimation.Our inversion-based interpretation method is successfully validated with challenging synthetic and field UDAR measurements acquired in the North Sea by various service companies. It is confirmed that the modeling and inversion algorithms are efficient, stable, and reliable for estimating geologically-plausible spatial distributions of anisotropic electrical conductivity around and ahead of the well trajectory.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students

event_summary: Speaker:Atul Sharma (Harvard University)
event_description: I will describe some miraculous simplifications that happen when studying the propagation of particles on a self-dual Taub-NUT spacetime. This is a gravitational instanton that provides a useful toy model of a black hole. Unlike real black holes, it allows for the computation of (tree-level) scattering amplitudes that are exact in the mass M, opening a window into non-perturbative strong field effects.
