event_title: AMO/IQSE seminar – Tutorial on Squeezed States and Applications to Quantum Metrology: Part 2
event_summary: Speaker: Girish S. Agarwal (IQSE, Texas A&M University)
event_description: I will present a tutorial on squeezed states for both Bosons and qubits. I will summarize their key properties and the methods to generate these. I would discuss the great importance of squeezed states in quantum metrology. These saturate quantum Cramer- Rao bounds in the estimation of a large number of parameters of interest. Thus, squeezed states produce Heisenberg limited sensing of parameters [1] like force fields; interferometric quantities like phases which enable one to extract quantities like concentration. I will then demonstrate how QCRB or Heisenberg limited sensing can be realized via standard quantum optical measurement of the error sensitivity in SU(1,1) interferometry. Remarkably enough these ideas are equally applicable to quantum networks [2] and open systems [3]._________________________Tutorial per invitation by Prof. Marlan Scully[1] G. S. Agarwal, and L. Davidovich, Quantifying quantum-amplified metrology via Fisher information, Phys. Rev. Res. 4, L 012014 (2022).[2] G. S. Agarwal, Saturation of Quantum Cramer-Rao Bounds for Distributed Sensing via Error Sensitivity in SU(1,1)-SU(m) Interferometry, ArXiv 2504.20225 V 1.[3] J. Wang, R. L. De Matos Filho, G. S. Agarwal, and L. Davidovich, Quantum advantage of time-reversed ancilla-based metrology of absorption parameters, Phys. Rev Res. 6, 013034 (2024).Professor Agarwal received M.S. from Banaras Hindu University in 1966, and a Ph.D. from the University of Rochester in 1969. He specializes primarily in quantum optics and broadly in quantum physics. The theoretical work focuses on quantum effects in hybrid systems; quantum phase transitions and collective effects in cavities driven by squeezed light; Frohlich condensates; coupling of quantum emitters to meta materials; chiral quantum systems. The experimental effort based on super-resolution microscopy, quantum sensing and is focused towards bio-photonics applications.Awards & HonorsMax Born Award (Optical Society of America, 1988)Humboldt Research Award (Humboldt Foundation Germany, 1997)The Physics Prize TWAS (The World academy of Sciences, 1994)Fellow Royal Society (The Royal Society, 2008)Charles Townes Medal (OPTICA formerly OSA, 2022)
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, researcher, students, visitors

event_title: Cosmic Fireworks: Supernovae through Polarized Light
event_summary: Speaker: Sergiy Vasylyev (University of California, Berkeley)
event_description: At the end of their lives, massive stars (more than 8 times the mass of the Sun) meet a cataclysmic fate, exploding as a supernova exceeding the Sun’s entire lifetime energy output in a single second! These cosmic explosions are responsible for synthesizing and dispersing heavy elements, enriching galaxies with the building blocks necessary for planet formation and life itself. Supernovae inject vast amounts of energy into their surrounding environments, influencing star formation and galactic evolution. Understanding these events is key to unraveling the chemical history of the universe and the cycle of stellar life and death. However, the precise mechanisms underlying these core collapse supernovae are not well understood. I will discuss how we probe these explosions and their complex environments using polarized light. I will discuss the current state of the field of spectropolarimetry, along with the state-of-the-art modeling efforts used to interpret observed polarimetric data.

event_title: Cosmic Cartography with Axion-Induced Gravitational Waves
event_summary: Speaker: Arushi Bodas (University of Chicago and Fermilab)
event_description: In this talk, I will present a novel scenario in which a rotating axion-like field in the early universe gives rise to a strong background of induced gravitational waves. Strikingly, this background can be highly anisotropic on large scales, directly reflecting axion fluctuations and offering a new observable beyond the CMB and large-scale structure, which trace adiabatic inflaton perturbations. I will discuss the dynamics of axion rotation, the resulting gravitational-wave signal and its anisotropy, and the prospects for probing this distinctive signature with future detectors.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, bryan-college station

event_title: Three Velocity Dynamical Theory of Supersolids
event_summary: W. Saslow, TAMU
event_description: There is now experimental evidence that a material can be both crystalline and superfluid, a seemingly impossible combination that has been studied theoretically for over fifty years, and quite recently experimentally. We first briefly review superfluidity, dating from the 1930’s and responsible for numerous Nobel Prizes. In 1969 Andreev and Lifshitz argued that the superfluidity of a solid is based on defect motion, proposed that such systems can have both superfluid and normal fluid components, and developed a dynamical theory for such a system. In 1970 Leggett argued that such a system has an overall quantum-mechanical phase whose gradient defines a superfluid velocity, and leads to a non-classical rotational inertia (NCRI). For a brief time around 2004 it was thought that solid 4He displays NCRI, but additional measurements showed that the observed effect was due to defects. However, in 2023 experiments on BEC dilute atomic solids revealed extra scattering spots when such a solid is rotated, which was interpreted as vortex line formation associated with superfluidity. Taking Leggett’s phase-flow viewpoint, we argue that at temperature T=0 a crystalline superfluid will have a superfluid fraction less than one, and thus missing mass. We resolve this by attributing a mass-bearing velocity to the solid. At finite T this system will have excitations and therefore a normal fluid velocity. Thus we consider that a supersolid has three mass-bearing velocities, each with its own velocity and response. We develop the dynamical theory of this system and discuss its expected experimental properties.

event_title: The Semitetrad Covariant Formulation of Gravity and Some Useful Applications
event_summary: Speaker: Sarbari Guha (St. Xavier’s College)
event_description: There are several methods of handling the highly nonlinear system of the Einstein field equations in order to derive the exact solutions or to extract the salient features of the corresponding spacetime dynamics. One such approach is the semi-tetrad covariant formalism of gravity. The semi-tetrad methods are the 1 + 3 covariant approach developed by Ehlers in 1961 and Ellis in 1971, and the 1 + 1 + 2 covariant approach developed by Clarkson and Barrett in 2003. The 1+3 formalism has generated new results in gauge-invariant study and specific spacetimes, among others. An extension of the 1+3 covariant approach is the 1+1+2 covariant approach, which has generated new results in locally rotationally symmetric spacetimes in General Relativity, and also illustrated other important features of gravitational dynamics, including gravitational collapse. I will offer a brief exposition to these two formalisms and discuss a few applications with particular reference to the 1 + 1 + 2 approach.

event_title: Bootstrapping the Physics at Finite Temperature
event_summary: Speaker:Minjae Cho (University of Chicago)
event_description: Physical systems at finite temperature present a rich array of intriguing questions. However, studying their physical observables is not always straightforward, as it a priori requires tracing over the entire state space. In this talk, we explore how the bootstrap approach of imposing consistency conditions provides a powerful framework for studying finite temperature observables in both statistical and quantum mechanical systems. We focus on two prototypical examples to illustrate this idea: the statistical Ising model on the lattice and large N ungauged matrix quantum mechanics. For the latter, we discuss bootstrap results for both one-point and two-point correlators.

event_title: Mapping Gravity with Extragalactic Streams and Citizen Science
event_summary: Speaker:Nathaniel Starkman (Massachusetts Institute of Technology)
event_description: Wide-field surveys like Euclid mark a new era of extragalactic stellar stream studies, with exciting applications in measuring baryon and dark matter distributions, and connecting galaxies to their cosmological context.I present results from a pilot study combining Euclid imaging with Zooniverse classifications to detect and analyze stellar streams of extragalactic systems. We use projected stream morphologies to constrain the shape and barycenter of each host galaxy’s potential, jointly probing baryonic and dark matter distributions. These inferences complement lensing, with sensitivity to halo geometry on tens of kpc scales. The method enables both stacked, population-level constraints on halo triaxiality and barycenters, and individual-halo inference on the same. Already, we find promising agreement with ΛCDM predictions. Our program will identify thousands of streams, enabling precise constraints on halo shapes and barycenters across large samples and redshifts, offering a new dynamical test of dark structures.

event_title: Deadline: Faculty Research Small Seed Grants
event_summary: The Race & Ethnic Studies Institute annually funds a number of Faculty Small Research Seed Grants up to $2,500 each. There will be two competitions – one in the Fall and one in the Spring.By default, the awards run for roughly one calendar year. We expect Fall awards to be announced in November and Spring awards to be announced in April. Funds will be set to expire and be returned one year after the funds have been awarded. Exceptions can be made; we just ask that any such requests are communicated to us in a timely manner (ideally as part of the application process).
event_description: ELIGIBILITY: Full-time faculty members for whom research is a formal component of their annual assessment are eligible to apply. Faculty must not have received an Interdisciplinary Faculty Seed Grant in the previous two years or a Faculty Small Research Seed Grants in the previous year.These awards are designed to address a need for funding for research that could not be accomplished otherwise in order to complete a book project, major article, or series of articles, or other equivalent research projects that makes an impact in the faculty member’s field and/or race and ethnic studies in general.Funds may be used for fieldwork, travel to archives, research materials, data sets, survey instruments, participant incentives, software, or other normally reimbursable expenses. The grant is not intended solely as a small grant to attend a conference, although proposals that include (or will lead to) presentations at conferences and workshops are strongly encouraged. The budget may not include stipend/salary or course buyouts. A portion of the funds may be used to support a graduate student working on the project, but the majority of the work should be undertaken by the awarded faculty member. For any questions about how the funds may be used, please contact RESI well before the deadline. Funds will be given as a bursary to be managed by the faculty member’s home department.Pending space availability, faculty will be invited to present at theRESI Faculty Colloquium Series. Awardees should acknowledge the Race & Ethnic Studies Institute in any resulting publications, presentations, or other work products funded; and will be asked to submit updates on their progress and products. Projects will be chosen on the basis of their intellectual rigor, scholarly creativity, and potential to make a significant impact in the candidate’s field and race and ethnic studies generally.FUNDING PRIORITIES: The Race & Ethnic Studies Institute is dedicated to fostering, celebrating, and producing cutting edge research related to race and ethnic studies. A wide range of research projects that examine the salience of race and ethnicity are of interest to RESI, however, proposals connecting to theRESI HSI Research Initiativeportfolio areparticularly encouraged. Texas A&M University is amongst the largest and most well resourced (in terms of total annual research expenditures) Hispanic-Serving Institutions in the country. RESI is strongly committed to building our university’s profile in HSI-related research. To best focus our research investment, we expect that somewhere between half and two-thirds of grants made will be channeled into the HSI Research Initiative portfolio.
event_category: deadlines, faculty, researcher, bryan-college station

event_summary: Thanks to the generous support of theMellon Foundationthrough ourLatinTX initiative, we are offering semester-long dissertation fellowships to doctoral candidates at Texas A&M University. Fellows will receive a $1000 research bursary, a monthly stipend during the semester, and coverage of usual tuition and fees during the semester of the award. In general, applicants should have been admitted to candidacy for a doctoral degree, completed all formal coursework (with a few exceptions), hold a minimum graduate GPA of 3.0, passed preliminary examination, and submitted an approved dissertation proposal. As this award is also intended to provide students with grant-writing experience, students are expected to work closely with their advisors on the materials being submitted. Advisors are expected to provide feedback on a draft proposal and write a confidential letter directly to RESI.Applicants are normally notified of award decisions by one month following the application deadline.
event_description: ELIGIBILITY: The fellowship is open to current graduate students at Texas A&M completing a dissertation on a humanistic research topic related to thethemes of the LatinTX initiative, including but not limited to critical environmental justice, environmental humanities, the Anthropocene, Latinx studies, critical/comparative/relational race and/or ethnic studies, decoloniality and decolonization, indigeneity, borderlands, migration, and more.By thetime of application, applicantsmustbe admitted to candidacy for a doctoral degree, have completed all formal coursework (with the exception for any remaining 681, 684, 690 and 691 credit hours), hold a minimum 3.0 Graduate GPA, have passed the preliminary examination (written and oral portions), and have submitted an approved dissertation proposal. While applicants may expect to defend their dissertations at the end of the semester of fellowship residence, they should not be graduating that semester. Priority will be given to students working within the fields listed above and further priority will be given to students in the College of Arts and Sciences.
event_category: deadlines, faculty, researcher, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: The Race & Ethnic Studies Institute (RESI) is offering a number of research grants to current Texas A&M University undergraduate students. This is, essentially, a major project grant to support the research enterprise leading to successful completion of some significant, faculty-directed project. In general, applicants should have second, third, or fourth-year standing; but RESI will consider proposals from exceptional students in their first year. As this award is also intended to provide students with grant-writing experience, students are expected to work closely with a faculty member on a project description, the rationale for the grant, and budget. Faculty are expected to provide feedback on a draft proposal and write a confidential letter directly to RESI.
event_description: ELIGIBILITY:To be eligible, applicants must be full-time or part-time undergraduate students in good standing at Texas A&M University. If a student applying for the Undergraduate Research Grants has previously had a project funded through another RESI program, they must have completed all requirements of that program, including reporting.GRANT EXPECTATIONS:The primary outcome should be a completed research project. Awardees should acknowledge the Race & Ethnic Studies Institute in any resulting publications, presentations, or other work products funded; and will be asked to submit updates on their progress and products.
event_category: deadlines, faculty, staff, students

event_title: How do we Science? Theorizing & Studying (In)Equity in Knowledge Production
event_summary: Join us for a talk with Dr. Allegra Midgette
event_description: Scholars in various fields have long called attention to the fact that there is consistent inequality in scientific knowledge production, both in terms of who gets to get their work published as well as the content of what is published (Dotson, 2012, 2014; Roberts et al., 2020; Settles et al., 2020). In the present talk, I present theKnowledge Production Pipeline (KPP) as a framework that serves to break down the scientific process into components to highlight how knowledge production can be (in) equitable. I also present recent findings of a mixed-methods study investigating scholars’ experiences of bias and inequality in the peer-review process, highlighting four distinct approaches to peer-review that contribute to issues in equity and quality in science production. I conclude with suggestions for teaching and implementing practices that contribute to a more equitable science.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_summary: The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service will host the 2025 Southwest Dairy Days on October. 9 in Dublin.
event_description: Participants will meet at the Double N Cowboy Church, 7202 E. State Highway 6 and bus tours to the Pepper Grass-fed Organic Dairy and Heifer Farm will offered from 9 a.m. to 2 p.m.Southwest Dairy Days is a program that gathers the dairy community on an educational field day. Its primary objectives are to give participants the opportunity to network and learn about new technologies and equipment dairy farmers could adopt on their farms.The largest dairy educational field day in Texas attracts approximately 500 participants annually, facilitating the adoption of cutting-edge knowledge in the industry.Two Dairy Outreach Program Area credits will be available for dairy producers to add to their nutrient management plan for compliance with theTexas Commission on Environmental Quality.Read more onAgriLife Today.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: 2025 Texas New Fruit Growers Conference: Day 1
event_summary: The Texas New Fruit Grower’s Conference is aTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceevent aimed at educating new and prospective fruit growers through classroom instruction, experiential learning, and peer-to-peer networking.
event_description: This one-and-a-half-day event exposes individuals with no previous farming or food production experience to an understanding of the unique challenges of managing a fruit orchard and vineyard.Participants will learn how to select an appropriate site, how to choose crops that grow successfully in their area of Texas, how to establish a vineyard or orchard and how to protect it from some of the unique weather and pest challenges that fruit growers encounter.The cost for the course is $130 per person. For AgriLife Extension employees the cost is $65. Online registration is available through Oct. 2 athttps://tx.ag/NFG2025.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, residents, staff

event_title: Water Well Screenings Interpretation Meeting: Bexar County
event_summary: TheTexas Well Owner Network, TWON, will host a results interpretation meeting for Bexar County residents on Oct. 9 in San Antonio.
event_description: This one-hour results interpretation meeting is the follow-up for residents who dropped off samples fortesting on Oct.7.Residents will also learn about water well protection practices and focuses on wellhead protection and recommendations for remediating well contamination.Read more onAgriLife Today.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: Entomology Fall 2025 Seminar Series: Fred Gould, Ph.D.
event_summary: The Department of Entomology is hosting an in-person and virtual weekly seminar series.
event_description: Fred Gould, Ph.D., William Neal Reynolds Distinguished Professor Emeritus at North Carolina State University, will present The interface of science and public values: Lessons from the past.Each week the Department of Entomology will host a visiting professors and researchers from other universities and science organizations who will present on their research topics related to the field of entomology.A ZOOM link will be provided for off-campus employees only.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, faculty, staff

event_summary: The Department of Horticultural Sciences will host Spirited Learning™ — a collaborative and interactive experience created to bring awareness to the diverse and vibrant horticulture industries in the state.
event_description: Each month, the event celebrates Texas Horticulture and feature a different Texas winery and welcomes their representatives to campus.  Representatives are on hand to chat with participants, share information about their business, and offer a tasting of their products and select wines during the event.This special edition of Spirited Learning is sponsored by Ball Horticultural Company.For more information on this or future Spirited Learning™ events, contact Amit Dhingra, professor and head of the Department of Horticultural Sciences atamit.dhingra@ag.tamu.edu.To register for the event, visithttps://forms.gle/xd38qBKXmwTuhi8D9.
event_category: open houses receptions, faculty, residents, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Cooking Well With Diabetes: McLennan County
event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Servicewill host the four-part “Cooking Well with Diabetes” series of classes on Thursday nights in Waco beginning Oct. 2.
event_description: The cost is $25 which covers all four classes. Online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/CookingWell25. Registration is also available by calling 254-299-8888. Deadline to register is Sept. 30.The goal of the program is to help those living with diabetes, family members or those just wanting to learn how to make changes to the foods we eat and how they are prepared.The four-lesson series examines carbohydrates, meal planning, and reducing fat and sodium while still maintaining flavorful dishes.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_description: The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, in collaboration with the Prescribed Burn Alliance of Texas, will host a free prescribed burn workshop on Oct. 10 from 8 a.m.–2 p.m. in Gatesville.The workshop will provide participants with key information on planning and implementing a prescribed burn and feature a hands-on demonstration.Registration for the free event is required athttps://tx.ag/PFWorkshop, and lunch will be provided

event_title: Crosby and Floyd County Field Day
event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Servicewill host a Crosby and Floyd County Field Day on Oct. 10.
event_description: The event is free, but registration is required by calling theTexas A&M AgriLife Research and Extension Centerat Lubbock at 806-746-6101. Registration deadline is Oct. 6.The event will include tours of three Replicated Agronomic Cotton Evaluation, RACE, trials. A lunch and cotton agronomy program update will follow.ThreeTexas Department of Agriculturecontinuing education units — two general and one integrated pest management — will be available.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_description: One Day 4-H is a one day event for all 4-H members, parents, leaders and volunteers to say thank you for supporting 4-H by giving back to their communities.In Stephens County, this day of community service consists of beautifying the downtown square and decorating for fall.All 4-H members, friends and family are invited.
event_category: youth (k-12)

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Servicewill host the Carr Ranch Gathering, a day of educational seminars, on Oct. 10.

Kleberg, Jr. and Helen C. Kleberg Endowed Chair, and executive director of the King Ranch Institute for Range Management at Texas A&M-Kingsville.Joe Paschal, Ph.D., AgriLife Extension specialist emeritus.T.R. Lansford, DVM,Texas Animal Health Commissiondeputy executive director and assistant state veterinarian.Lance Bauer, Ph.D., executive vice president, Beefmaster Breeder United.

event_title: Johnson County Landowner Series: Gardening and Canning
event_summary: The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension office for Johnson County will be holding a landowners series in Cleburne.
event_description: The series consists of four sessions on Oct. 10, Oct. 24, Nov. 7 and Nov. 14. Each session is $10 and payable by cash or check at the door. To RSVP, call 817-556-6370 at least one day prior to the session you would like to attend.Topics include:Session 1 — Basics of gardening, tour of Guinn Garden, canning and food preservation.Session 2 — Pasture management 101, cottage food laws, panelist of famers market sellers.Session 3 — Backyard poultry, homesteading, basics of animal handling.Session 4 — Goals of land management, business planning and financial, county resources to know.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, residents

event_title: 4-H Shooting Sports Certified Coaches Training: District 4

event_description: This is a two-day shooting sports certified coaches training for volunteers.

event_title: 3rd Annual Boo-tanical Fall Festival and Plant Sale
event_summary: Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service and the Cameron County Master Gardeners will host the 3rd Annual Botanical Fall Festival and Plant Sale in San Benito.
event_description: The free event will be held at the Education Garden located within the gates of the Cameron County Annex. The event will take place rain or shine and costumes are encouraged.Attendees will be able to shop a variety of native and butterfly plants, vegetables, herbs and more. There will be food, activities for kids, educational booths to learn about gardening as well as unique plants and goodies.
event_category: open houses receptions, residents

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceoffice in McLennan County and McLennan Community College will host a kids in the kitchen cooking class.
event_description: The cost of the class is $25 and online registration is available atMCC Continuing Education. Registration is also available by calling MCC Continuing Education at 254-299-8888. Deadline to register is Oct. 9. The class is open to youth ages 8-16.Participants will explore foods from around the world. and gain hands-on cooking experience. They will learn basic kitchen skills, food safety practices, knife skills and how to prepare simple, delicious meals.
event_category: training workshops, youth (k-12)

event_summary: The Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service will offer a hunter education course on Oct. 11 in Tilden.
event_description: The course fee is $15. Instructors may also apply additional range or facility fees. Participants must register athttps://tx.ag/HuntersEducationTilden.The one-day course is designed for novice or young hunters, ages 9 and up. Enrollment is limited to 15 participants. Priority will be given to 4-H youth and their families, but individual adults may enroll if space allows.Participants will learn firearm and hunting safety, hunting ethics, and wildlife conservation. The course provides up to six hours of classroom instruction.Certified volunteer instructors will lead the course and all materials will be provided.
event_category: training workshops, youth (k-12)

event_title: Wildflowers for the Four States Area
event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, Bowie County Master Gardeners and Texas A&M-Texarkana School of Professional Education and Community Education will host “Wildflowers for the Four States Area,” on Oct. 13.
event_description: The event is free, and no preregistration is required.Jay Caddel, AgriLife Extension agriculture and natural resources agent for Tarrant County, will present the program. Caddel is well-versed in wildflowers and previously worked as the nursery manager for the Lady Bird Johnson Wildflower Center in Austin.Participants will learn practical tips on how to incorporate wildflowers and other native plants into their landscape.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: Texas Riparian and Stream Ecosystem Education Program: Upper Medina Watershed
event_summary: TheTexas Water Resources Institute, TWRI, will host a freeTexas Riparian and Stream Ecosystem Education Programon Oct. 14 in Medina.
event_description: Attendees must RSVP by Oct. 7 attx.ag/Medina25or by contacting Alexander Neal, TWRI program specialist, Bryan-College Station, atAlexander.Neal@ag.tamu.edu. The program will include a lunchtime presentation. A catered lunch will be available for $15, or attendees may bring their own lunch.The program is for citizens interested in land and water stewardship in the Upper Medina River watershed.The workshop is co-hosted by the Bandera County River Authority and Groundwater District,Texas A&M AgriLife Extension ServiceandTexas Riparian Association.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: Nourish to Flourish: Nutrition Strategies for Breast Cancer Survivors
event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Service, in partnership withOneOp, will present the webinar “Nourish to Flourish: Nutrition Strategies for Breast Cancer Survivors” at 10 a.m., Oct. 23.
event_description: There is no cost to attend, but registration is required athttps://oneop.org/learn/160105. Once registered, participants will receive a confirmation email with information on how to connect to the webinar.The webinar will provide breast cancer survivors with practical, evidence-based guidance on how food and lifestyle choices can support healing, recovery and long-term wellness.The webinar will be presented by Whitney Warminski, a board certified specialist in oncology nutrition.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: Texas Master Naturalist 2025 Annual Meeting: Day 1
event_summary: The Texas Master Naturalist 2025 Annual Meeting will be held on October. 16-19 in College Station.
event_description: Registration for the event opens on August. 1 and is available online athttps://tx.ag/2025TMNAnnualMeeting.Early bird registration is available through Aug. 31 and is $480 for the full event, $455 for two days (Friday and Saturday) or $305 for one day (Thursday, Friday or Saturday).Registration after August. 31 is $530, $505 and $355, respectively. The deadline to register is Sept. 30.The annual meeting is an opportunity for Texas Master Naturalist volunteers from around to gather, participate in hands-on educational seminars and receive their advanced training requirements for the year in one weekend.It also provides an opportunity for program participants and supporters to network, share new ideas and learn from chapters in different regions of the state.
event_category: open houses receptions, training workshops, residents

event_summary: The GO GRAD Fair is an opportunity for graduate and professional school representatives to visit Texas A&M.
event_description: During this in-person visit, representatives will meet with students, faculty and staff to share information about graduate or professional degree programs available at the institution they represent.Any and all students interested in pursuing a master’s, Ph.D., or professional degree program of study should make plans to attend this annual event.All students, faculty and staff are welcome to attend. This event is also open to the local community and the general public.For more information, visithttps://tamu-csm.symplicity.com/events/cb7666488908d9587d35496a3088edb4/overviewSponsored by the Career Center and Graduate and Professional School
event_category: training workshops, students, bryan-college station

event_title: Medina River Watershed Protection Plan Meeting
event_summary: The Texas Water Resources Institute, TWRI, invites local stakeholders to a public meeting to discuss the next steps for theMedina River Below Medina Diversion Lake Watershed Protection Planon Oct. 16 in Castroville.
event_description: The free public meeting will include updates on social media engagement, outreach successes and challenges, and upcoming workshops and events from TWRI staff.Stakeholders will also be invited to provide feedback on outreach needs and to participate in the design of a new Medina River WPP logo, ensuring the plan has a clear identity that reflects the community it serves.

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceoffice in McLennan County and McLennan Community College are offering a Professional Food Manager Certification Training course.
event_description: The cost of the two-day course is $125, which includes training materials, and theServSafeNational Food Manager Certification exam. Certification is valid anywhere in Texas for five years.Online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/FoodManager. Space is limited and the deadline to register is Oct. 6.This program is designed to prepare foodservice managers to pass the ServSafe certification exam, and it will provide valuable education regarding the safe handling of food, sanitation, food flow, managing the operation and Hazard Analysis Control Point, HACCP.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: Backyard Chicken seminar series: Chicken Basics
event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Servicewill host a Backyard Chicken Basics workshop.
event_description: The virtual workshop is part of the Backyard Chicken seminar series presented by AgriLife Extension and theDepartment of Poultry Sciencethat includes weekly seminars on topics related to backyard poultry.The workshop is comprised of four modules, with one module being covered each day. The workshop is free and online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/BackyardChickenSeries25.Daily topics include:Oct. 20 — Introduction, housing and lighting.Oct. 21 — Breeds and nutrition.Oct. 22 — Selling eggs and poultry, food safety.Oct. 23 — Health and disease.Oct. 24 — Chickens, your garden, and the environment.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_title: David McKnight ’73 Ranch Management University: Day 1
event_summary: The award-winningDavid McKnight ’73 Ranch Management Universityis scheduled for Oct. 20-24 at the Scotts Miracle-Gro Turf Facility.
event_description: The cost of the event is $525 for general registration, $325 for military, veterans, law enforcement and first responders, and $250 forTexas A&M AgriLifeemployees. Online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/RMU2025.This short course, named in honor of ranching enthusiast David McKnight, is a critical educational initiative designed to help new and inexperienced landowners understand the fundamentals of natural resource management. Through applied learning and foundational information, the program empowers participants to make financially sound decisions, optimize land productivity, and maximize long-term land stewardship.By putting the pieces together, landowners gain practical knowledge they can take back to their piece of Texas and apply with confidence.
event_category: speakers, forums, and conferences, training workshops, residents

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceand theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Boardin cooperation with theTexas Water Resources Institutewill host aTexas Watershed Stewardworkshop on the Big Elm Creek and other nearby watersheds on Oct. 20 in Cameron.
event_description: The free event is open to anyone interested in improving the region’s water quality. Participants must pre-register by visiting the Texas Watershed Steward website athttps://tws.tamu.edu/workshops/registration/or by calling 979-321-5935.The workshop will cover Big Elm Creek, Deer Creek, Pond Creek, Middle Yegua Creek and Brushy Creek.It will include a discussion on watershed systems, along with types and sources of water pollution. There will also be a group discussion on community-driven watershed protection and management and an overview of water quality as it relates to watershed management at the local level.
event_category: training workshops, residents

event_summary: TheTexas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceand McLennan Community College will host a Taste of the Mediterranean diet cooking class Oct. 28 in Waco.
event_description: The cost of the class is $25 and online registration is available athttps://tx.ag/Mediterranean. Space is limited and the deadline to register is Oct. 26.The Mediterranean diet is a way of eating and preparing foods in the U.S. based on traditions from Italy, Greece and other countries that border the Mediterranean Sea.Plant-based foods including whole grains, vegetables, legumes, fruits and nuts, herbs and spices are the foundation of the diet. Fish, dairy, poultry and seafood are all eaten in moderation, and olive oil is a main source of fat in this type of diet.Rachel Esquivel, AgriLife Extensionfamily and community healthagent for McLennan County, will teach the class.

event_title: CDE - Innovative Dentistry: Exploring 3D Printing for New Practitioners
event_summary: Course SummaryThis introductory course is designed for dentists who are new to 3D printing technology. Participants will explore the transformative potential of 3D printing in modern dental practices, learning how this innovative technology can enhance precision, efficiency, and patient care. This course is ideal for dentists who have little to no experience with 3D printing and are interested in learning how to integrate this technology into their practice to improve patient outcomes and streamline operations.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-309d3f6d79ae472ab2c1785f98a9bdc3
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Understand the fundamentals of 3D printing technology and its application in the dental field.Identify the various uses of 3D printing in dentistry.Recognize the benefits of integrating 3D printing into dental practices.Evaluate the necessary equipment and software required to start using 3D printing in their practice.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_title: CDE - Providing Care to the Special Needs Patient
event_summary: Course SummaryCaring for patients with special health care needs comes with unique challenges that the dental clinician is not always prepared for. This course is designed to help give you the perspective and skills for treating, educating, and supporting patients with disabilities. We will review pertinent behavioral management principles and historical perspectives that will help you be successful in serving the special needs patient.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-b34458d519934f58adda08a5bb5110bb
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Review the history of disability around the world.Review common disability conditions the dental clinician may encounter.Learn behavioral management principles that will help special needs patients have a better dental experience.Review some of the most common treatment challenges and how to overcome them.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_title: CDE - Bone Preservation Strategies Following Severe Traumatic Dental Injuries in Children
event_summary: Course SummarySevere traumatic dental injuries (TDIs) in young patients can result in unrestorable teeth or replacement resorption and ankylosis with the potential for infra-occlusion in growing children. Extraction is often the treatment rendered in these cases. When permanent teeth are subsequently extracted, long-term complications are likely. The supporting bone will be lost, creating the need for additional interventions later in life when the patient is ready for a more permanent option to rehabilitate the area. In the meantime, young, growing patients have limited prosthetic options if a tooth is lost. Bone preservation in young patients is of paramount importance. When patients are ready for definitive tooth replacement (eg. implant), previous bone preservation can make the process simpler and less costly as the need for bone and soft tissue augmentation may be minimal or unnecessary. This presentation will cover a series of clinical cases where bone preservation strategies were employed when treating young patients following severe TDIs. This presentation will emphasize how a multidisciplinary approach is paramount to achieve optimal results, where the endodontist needs to collaborate with periodontists, oral surgeons, orthodontists and general dentists.REGISTER:https://reg.learningstream.com/reg/event_page.aspx?ek=0069-0031-d1f4b6742b994ee897de8e0a2b173643
event_description: ObjectivesUpon completion of this course, you will be able to:Review types of trauma that can aid in the need for bone preservation.Understand the importance of bone preservation in the young, growing patient.Articulate options for bone preservation in young patients.Highlight the importance of multidisciplinary collaboration.
event_category: training workshops, faculty, researcher, residents, staff, students, visitors, dallas

event_title: Riparian and Stream Ecosystem Workshop: Medina River Watershed
event_summary: This training will focus on the nature and function of stream and riparian zones and the benefits and direct impacts from healthy riparian zones. This workshop is being co-hosted by the Bandera County River Authority & Groundwater District, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension & Research and the Texas Water Resources Institute.
event_description: The riparian education programs will cover an introduction to riparian principles, watershed processes, basic hydrology, erosion/deposition principles and riparian vegetation, as well as potential causes of degradation and possible resulting impairment(s) and available local resources, including technical assistance and tools that can be employed to prevent and/or resolve degradation.RSVP by October 7, 2025These one-day trainings in watersheds across the state include both indoor classroom presentations and outdoor stream walks. Instructors are experts from the Bandera County River Authority & Groundwater District, Texas Parks and Wildlife Department, USDA Natural Resources Conservation Service, Texas A&M Forest Service and Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service.The goal is for participants to better understand and relate to riparian and watershed processes, the benefits that healthy riparian areas provide and the tools that can be employed to prevent and/or resolve degradation and improve water quality. At the conclusion of the training, participants will receive a certificate of completion.Continuing Education Units Available:Texas Department of Agriculture Pesticide Applicators License - 3 CEUsTexas Nutrient Management Planning Specialists - 6 hoursInternational Society of Arboriculture - 8.25 CEUs (Certified Arborist: 2.75, Municipal Specialist: 2.75, BCMA - Science: 0.75, BCMA - Practice: 2)Texas Forestry Association - 6 hoursSociety of American Foresters - 6 hoursSociety for Range Management – 7 CEUsCertified Crop Advisor- 7 CEUs (Nutrient Mgmt: 1, Soil & Water: 1.5, IPM: 1.5, Crop Mgmt: 2.5, Manure Mgmt: 0.5)Texas Board of Architectural Examiners “Acceptable for HSW credit”Texas Floodplain Management Association – 7 CECsThe program may also be used for CEUs for Professional Engineers.Check with your Chapter for Master Naturalist and Master Gardener to see if it is approved for your area. This course is approved for the Texas Waters Specialist certification program.Registration is required by October 7, 2025.A catered lunch will be available to participants for $15. Lunch can be paid for in advance by credit card or in cash on-site the day of the event. Participants may also choose to bring their own lunch. Dress is casual and comfortable for the weather as we will be outside along a nearby stream during the afternoon.For more information or questions please contact Alexander Neal atAlexander.Neal@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-2351. This workshop is free because the program is funded through a Clean Water Act grant provided by the Texas State Soil and Water Conservation Board and U.S. Environmental Protection Agency.Please join ourlistservor like our partnering organization onFacebookfor more information on future programs!
event_category: training workshops

event_title: Medina River Watershed Protection Plan Meeting
event_summary: The Texas Water Resources Institute, TWRI, invites local stakeholders to a public meeting to discuss the next steps for theMedina River Below Medina Diversion Lake Watershed Protection Plan(WPP) on Oct. 16 in Castroville.
event_description: The free public meeting will be from 1-3 p.m. at the Braden Keller Community Center, 1410 Amelia St, in Castroville.The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA)recently acceptedthe WPP for the Medina River below Medina Diversion Lake as meeting EPA guidelines for watershed-based plans. The plan outlines a strategy to implement management measures that will help improve and protect water quality in the watershed.“Acceptance of the plan is a result of collaboration between watershed stakeholders, the San Antonio River Authority, and Texas A&M AgriLife and TWRI,” said Tina Hendon, TWRI program specialist. “Local residents, agricultural producers, business and industry representatives, city and county personnel and other interested parties provided valuable input for development of the plan.”With EPA’s recent acceptance, this meeting will focus on building momentum for implementation and will highlight the role of community partners in supporting healthy landscapes and clean water.Meeting highlightsThe agenda includes updates on social media engagement, outreach successes and challenges, and upcoming workshops and events from TWRI staff. Stakeholders will also be invited to provide feedback on outreach needs and to participate in the design of a new Medina River WPP logo, ensuring the plan has a clear identity that reflects the community it serves.Guest presentations will feature:Nathan Glavy, technical director,Greater Edwards Aquifer Alliance (GEAA), discussing GEAA support of local efforts and their “Building Healthy Landscapes” workshop.Kason Haby, technical assistance specialist, Texas Grazing Lands Coalition covering soil health and grazing land stewardship practices that benefit both producers and water quality.Lee Albee, owner and rancher, Southwest Farms, discussing generative agriculture on his operation and the services available to local producers.“Implementation is about more than just projects — it’s about people and partnerships,” said Mary Michael Zahed, TWRI program specialist. “This meeting is a chance for stakeholders to see how local organizations and producers are putting conservation into practice and to help shape the future of the watershed.”Funding for this effort is provided through a federal Clean Water Act Section 319(h) grant from theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency, administered by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Board.TWRI is aTexas A&M AgriLife Researchunit that brings together expertise from acrossThe Texas A&M University System.For more information, contact Zahed atmary.lipfordzahed@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-8092. Read more about the watershed atmedina.twri.tamu.edu.

event_title: Davidson Creek Public Meeting and Expert Panel
event_summary: October 21:The Texas Water Resources Institute (TWRI) invites community members, landowners, and anyone with interest in local water quality to attend the fifth public meeting for the Davidson Creek Watershed Protection Plan (WPP), where hot spots for potential bacteria pollution will be presented and followed by a panel discussion featuring experts in watershed management and conservation practices.
event_description: The meeting will take place onTuesday, October 21, at 12:00 p.m.at the Burleson County Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Service Office, 1516 FM 166, Caldwell, Texas.(Please note: the Extension Office is no longer located at the county courthouse.)There is no requirement for participants to have attended prior meetings, anyone interested can catch up by reviewing notes and presentations from previous meetings on the Davidson Creek website meetings tabhttps://davidson.twri.tamu.edu/meetings/.The event is hosted by the Davidson Creek Watershed Partnership in collaboration with Burleson County AgriLife Extension and aims to share critical location-based analysis that supports the ongoing development of the WPP. Attendees will learn how and where hot spots were located for potential bacteria loading across the watershed. The findings will help prioritize areas for targeted conservation efforts and Best Management Practices (BMPs). Attendees will also have the opportunity to ask questions from panel of experts on implementing BMPs across central Texas to improve water quality.Public input is strongly encouraged. Your voice and involvement are critical to the success of this plan.Funding for developing the Davidson Creek WPP is provided by the Texas State Soil and Water Conservation Board, through the State Nonpoint Source Grant Program.TWRI is part of Texas A&M AgriLife Research, Texas A&M AgriLife Extension and the College of Agriculture and Life Sciences at Texas A&M University.While RSVP is not required for attendance, please RSVP to the event by 10/16 so we can prepare materials and handoutshttps://forms.office.com/r/cuwYdUxVQL. For more information, contact Amanda Tague atamanda.tague@ag.tamu.edu. Read more about this watershed atDavidson.twri.tamu.edu.

event_title: Land Smart Workshop - Medina River Watershed
event_summary: Land Smart: A Guide to Small Acreage StewardshipOctober 25:Free workshop for new and small-acreage landowners in Medina River watershed in Castroville from 8:30 a.m. - 2:00 p.m.Registeronlineathttp://tx.ag/landsmart2025or call 830-426-2521 ext. 3.
event_description: Medina County is seeing many new faces as families move from city life to the countryside. To help small-acreage landowners understand their property and make informed decisions, the Texas Water Resources Institute (TWRI), Medina Valley Soil and Water Conservation District (MVSWCD), and other partners are hosting a workshop,Land Smart: A Guide to Small Acreage Stewardship,onSaturday, October 25, 2025, from 8:30 AM – 2:00 PM at the St. Louis Braden Keller Community Center in Castroville.The event is free and open to the public and includes breakfast and lunch.“It is easy to feel overwhelmed with the possibilities of what to do with new property and many new landowners in the Medina River Watershed are likely wondering, now what?” said Mary Michael Zahed, Medina River watershed coordinator, TWRI. “This workshop was designed especially for new landowners with those with 1-50 acres of land.”The workshop will cover topics such as understanding Medina County soils, water, and vegetation; land use options like livestock, wildlife, and beekeeping; tax benefits for agriculture and wildlife exemptions; and local programs and funding sources. Hands-on demonstrations, including a rainfall simulator and watershed model, will show conservation practices in action.A panel discussion will feature experts from theMedina Valley Soil and Water Conservation District, Texas Water Resources Institute, Texas Grazing Land Coalition, Wildlife Habitat Federation, USDA–Natural Resources Conservation Service, and USDA–Farm Service Agency.This is an opportunity for landowners to ask local experts questions about their property and land management options.“This workshop is designed to inform smaller-acreage landowners of their opportunities, including land management, conservation objectives, and tax options.” said Wayne Stein, MVSWCD Chair. “Come join us for food and knowledge.”The event isfreeand includes a light breakfast and lunch.Registration is requested to help plan meals.Register online athttp://tx.ag/landsmart2025or call 830-426-2521 ext. 3.Funding for this project is provided in part by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Board Stateas part of a Clean Water Act Section 319(h) Grant from theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency.TWRI is a unit ofTexas A&M AgriLife Researchthat brings together expertise from acrossThe Texas A&M University System.For more information, contact Zahed atmary.lipfordzahed@ag.tamu.eduor 979-314-8092. Read more about the watershed atmedina.twri.tamu.edu.
event_category: training workshops

event_title: Well Water Screening: Walker and Grimes County
event_summary: October 27:Water samples can be dropped off from 8:30 - 10:30 a.m. at the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office, 203 Veterans Memorial Drive, Navasota or the Walker County AgriLife Extension office, 102 Tam Road, Suite B, Huntsville.October 28:Results and educational meeting from 8:30 a.m. to 12:30 p.m. at the Huntsville Public Library, 1219 13thStreet, Huntsville.Cost:$15 per water sampleRSVPto Joel Pigg atj-pigg@tamu.edubyOctober 22to ensure adequate meeting room size.
event_description: Residents of Walker and Grimes County are invited to water well screenings and education meetings.TheTexas Well Owner Network, TWON, is holding an upcoming event on October 27-28. This program allows residents to have their private well water screened, as well as provide education training for groundwater protection. This event is hosted by the Bluebonnet Groundwater Conservation District, the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office and the Walker County AgriLife Extension office. It is open to the public and free to attend, lunch will be provided.Joel Pigg,Texas A&M AgriLife Extension Serviceprogram specialist, College Station, said the Texas Well Owner Network program is for Texas residents who depend on household wells for their water needs.“The TWON program was established to help well owners become familiar with Texas groundwater resources, septic system maintenance, well maintenance and construction, and water quality and treatment,” he said.Water samples will be screened for contaminants, including total coliform bacteria, E. coli bacteria, nitrate-nitrogen and salinity.Sampling instructionsPlease use a new bottle of water (12-20 ounces), pour out the contents and fill it with a water sample from your private water well. Take the sample from the spigot/hose bib nearest to the well head. Remove the water hose if there is one and take directly from the spigot/hose bib. If an inside faucet is used, you will need to remove the aerator on faucet before making the collection. Rinse and dry the exterior of the faucet to prevent exterior contamination of your water sample. If possible, wipe off with a Clorox-type towelette or paper towel wetted with a light bleach solution to kill any bacteria present on the faucet.Allow the solution to dry before sampling.Turn on the water full force and let it run at full force for two minutes or until you hear the pump start running. Reduce the water flow to a small stream and collect the sample.Refrigerate the sample and transport it to the workshop (in an ice chest) as soon after collection as possible. It is best to collect the day of the workshop if possible ;otherwise make sure the sample is kept cool and out of direct sunlight. Sample should be collected within 24 hours before the workshop to ensure accurate results.We encourage you to bring samples from all wells on your property; many participants that have water treatment equipment take samples before and after treatment to make sure the equipment is functioning properly. We need for you to label the sample with your name (if you bring more than one sample you also need to label the sample in a way to make sure you know which well the sample comes from). We will be screening for Nitrates, TDS (salinity) and bacteria (absence or presence of coliform and E. coli) with your sample.There will be a $15 per sample charge for this water well screening and you may bring as many samples as you would like.Pigg said it is essential for those submitting samples to be at the follow-up meeting to receive results, learn corrective measures for identified problems and improve their understanding of private well management.Water contaminants concernsPigg said research shows the presence ofE. colibacteria in water indicates that waste from humans or warm-blooded animals may have contaminated the water. Water contaminated withE. coliis more likely to also have pathogens that can cause diarrhea, cramps, nausea or other symptoms.The presence of nitrate-nitrogen in well water is also a concern, and water with nitrate-nitrogen at levels of 10 parts per million is considered unsafe for human consumption, he said.“These nitrate levels above 10 parts per million can disrupt the ability of blood to carry oxygen throughout the body, resulting in a condition called methemoglobinemia,” Pigg said. “Infants less than 6 months of age are the most susceptible to this.”Salinity, as measured by total dissolved solids, will also be determined for each sample, he said. Water with high levels may leave deposits and have a salty taste. Using water with high levels for irrigation may damage soil or plants.To learn more about the program or to find additional publications and resources, visittwon.tamu.edu. For more information on the water screening contact Pigg at 979-321-5946 orj-pigg@tamu.edu.The screenings are presented by Texas A&M AgriLife Extension andTexas Water Resources Institute, TWRI.Funding for TWON are through a Clean Water Act Section 319(h) nonpoint source grant provided by theTexas State Soil and Water Conservation Boardand theU.S. Environmental Protection Agency. The project is managed by TWRI, part ofTexas A&M AgriLife Research, AgriLife Extension and theTexas A&M College of Agriculture and Life Sciences.For more information specific to the workshop, contact the Grimes County AgriLife Extension office at 936-873-3907, Walker County AgriLife Extension Office at 936-435-2426, or the Bluebonnet Groundwater Conservation District at 936-825-7303 or Joel Pigg atj-pigg@tamu.eduor 979-321-5946.

event_summary: Learn practical tools to effectively manage concerns related to perfectionism from professionally trained staff.
event_description: Learn the myths and consequences of perfectionistic thinking. Attendees will also learn strategies to challenge perfectionistic thinking and how to set healthy and realistic goals.
event_category: general interest, international students, training workshops

event_title: 5 Ways Chronic Stress Alerts Your Brain and How to Safeguard Your Mental Wellbeing
event_summary: Bring your lunch and learn how to take control of your mental health.
event_description: This lunch-and-learn workshop features a video by Dr. Tracey Marks, a psychiatrist who focuses on the brain-body connection and how to improve overall well-being. Marks has more than 20 years of clinical experience treating ADHD. Attendees will then engage in open discussion.
event_category: general interest, training workshops, students, bryan-college station

event_title: UWC Grad Writing Workshop: Improving Your Flow
event_summary: Join the University Writing Center for our Graduate Writing Workshop, “Improving Your Flow,” where we’ll discuss what effective flow in writing is and how you can achieve it.
event_description: Join the University Writing Center for our Graduate Writing Workshop, “Improving Your Flow,” where we’ll discuss what effective flow in writing is and how you can achieve it. After our workshop you’ll be able to:Recognize the importance of flow in writingConsider audience needs & expectationsIdentify linguistic strategies for linking & transitioningLearn to improve the flow of your writing with those strategiesYou can sign up here:https://ers.tamu.edu/register.aspx?ScheduleId=45841Once you register for the event, you’ll receive an email from ERS confirming your registration; then, two days before the event, you’ll receive an email from Lauren McAuliffe (lmcauliffe@tamu.edu) to remind you of the event and provide you with the zoom link.We’re excited to see you there!
event_category: faculty, staff, students, bryan-college station

event_description: This workshop helps participants enhance their teaching and public speaking skills through microteaching demonstrations delivered in a low-risk environment. Each participant delivers a 5-minute presentation, receiving constructive feedback from a consultant and an undergraduate student on pronunciation, presentation structure, visual aids, nonverbal communication and more. By presenting in front of a friendly audience, participants develop confidence, and by observing peers' presentations, they gain additional insight into best practices for comprehensible and well-developed presentations.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Construct and deliver short, well-structured and intelligible presentations.2.Create a visual aid to support key points.3.Identify areas for improvement in their own presentations and those of their peers.If you wish to attend but do not wish to present, please note that you are allowed to atten

event_title: GSPDT -  Active Learning in the Classroom
event_description: Discover practical active learning strategies to boost student engagement and participation. Using the CTE's active learning guide, this session will provide easy-to-implement techniques to make your teaching more interactive, inclusive, and effective—no matter the subject or class size.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Define active learning and explain its benefits in higher education settings.2. Identify at least three active learning strategies appropriate for different classroom formats (lecture, discussion, lab, etc.).3. Design a brief activity or lesson segment using an active learning strategy aligned with their course goals.

event_title: Hear from Peers: Experimenting with AI in Italian Language and Culture courses
event_description: This webinar series invites faculty members from diverse disciplines to come together and explore the multifaceted landscape of generative AI. Through a series of engaging discussions and presentations, we will explore themes such as AI literacy and informed decision making, guidelines and policy for integrating AI in the classroom, responsibility and boundaries of AI-generated content, and ethics.Whether you’re an expert in the use of AI or just curious about the possibilities of AI, this workshop series promises to broaden your horizons. The webinar sessions take place on a weekly basis.

The Let’s Talk program is an outreach initiative that meets and engages students in conversation with a UHS counselor in an environment that feels safe to them. Let’s Talk @ ISSS program is specifically designed for international students and the questions and concerns that they have. During a session, you are encouraged to discuss any topic that you feel is impacting your physical, mental, or academic health.

event_title: Conversation Circle for English Language Proficiency
event_description: Conversation Circle is a supportive space for practicing spoken English through group discussions on cultural topics, including American university culture. Participants improve spontaneous speaking, active listening, and conversational turn-taking. Through communication with speakers from a variety backgrounds, they acclimate to different accents. The sessions promote social connections, intercultural dialogue, and a sense of belonging. The goal is to enhance English fluency, comprehension, and confidence.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to:1. Employ effective spontaneous communication skills in social, academic and professional settings.2. Elaborate on their viewpoints and opinions in group discussions.3. Construct clear and well-structured responses during impromptu conversations.4. Apply appropriate turn-taking and active listening techniques in casual group discussions and more formal academic discussions.

Looking for a peaceful space to read, relax, and connect with fellow book lovers? Join us for a Silent Book Club event! Unlike traditional book clubs, there's no required reading or pressure to discuss. Bring your own book or pick one from our selection, settle into a cozy spot, and enjoy an hour of quiet reading. Afterward, if you’d like, stay to chat about what you're reading or simply enjoy the company of other readers. All are welcome, whether you're an avid reader or just looking for a moment of calm.

A peer-led support group where Bush School transfer students come together to navigate academic challenges, build your knowledge-base, and share insider tips from upperclassmen, advisors, and faculty. We don't only want you to survive, we want you to thrive!

event_title: Academic English Communication Skills: Office Hours (Part 2)
event_description: Many teaching assistants and professors have the important responsibility of conducting office hours, in which students bring a range of questions and concerns. This workshop is for current and future TAs and professors who use English as a Second Language, or American English as a second dialect. In this workshop (Part 2), American undergraduate students will join and participate in a role-play, simulating interactions between instructors and students during office hours, preparing both parties for successful intercultural interactions in an academic setting. Note: This is a two-part workshop. Part 2 is restricted to those who attended Part 1. Those who attend Part 1 will automatically be registered for Part 2. Register for Part 1 at https://ers.tamu.edu/event/8335

The recent Title II revision (the Final Rule) mandates that all digital content meet accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users. Part of the Digital Accessibility Series, this session focuses on PDF files. PDF files can be among the most challenging to remediate. In this session, we will address the common challenges associated with PDF remediation. The workshop will explore typical accessibility issues found in PDF files. Participants will have the opportunity to use Adobe Acrobat’s built-in accessibility checker and practice with this tool.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Identify common accessibility issues with PDF files.2. Discuss some limitations to remediation of PDF files.3. Evaluate the accessibility of PDF files using Adobe Acrobat built-in accessibility checker.
Ready to take the next step in your academic journey? Join us in the WCSS ERL to learn more about and apply to the MS ECON 3+2 Program!

This four-session pronunciation workshop systematically explores the vocal tract and segments of speech that make meaningful differences in North American English. Through a variety of activities and handouts, attendees will become familiar with each consonant sound and with resources to practice listening discrimination and accurate pronunciation on their own. They each have the opportunity to get personalized feedback on their own pronunciation.

event_title: Digital Accessibility Series Fall 25 – Session 3: Enhancing Accessibility of PDF Files
event_description: The recent Title II revision (the Final Rule) mandates that all digital content meet accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users. Part of the Digital Accessibility Series, this session focuses on PDF files. PDF files can be among the most challenging to remediate. In this session, we will address the common challenges associated with PDF remediation.The workshop will explore typical accessibility issues found in PDF files. Participants will have the opportunity to use Adobe Acrobat’s built-in accessibility checker and practice with this tool.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Identify common accessibility issues with PDF files.2) Discuss some limitations to remediation of PDF files.3) Evaluate the accessibility of PDF files using Adobe Acrobat built-in accessibility checker.

event_title: Rec Your Day: Get Moving with Transfers!
event_description: Curious about a group Recxercise class? Join us and we'll take the Party at the Barre class at the Rec Center. It’s fun, low pressure, and working out is always better with new friends. To ensure your spot, please RSVP with the Rec using the link provided on the calendar!

event_title: Academy for Future Faculty - Understanding Institutional Structure
event_description: The AFF Executive Committee will discuss navigating institutional differences in higher education. Participants will examine how various types of institutions—such as research universities, teaching-focused colleges, and community colleges—may emphasize different qualifications, skills, and experiences in faculty roles. The session will provide insights to help graduate students better understand institutional priorities and prepare for diverse career opportunities in academia.Participants will be able to:1. Compare the priorities of different types of higher education institutions.2. Analyze how institutional structures influence faculty roles and responsibilities.3. Prepare to tailor application materials and professional goals to institutional expectations."
Open the door to career opportunities and advancement! Learn more about the FE Exam, the first step in the process of becoming a Professional Engineer (P.E.).

event_title: Explaining Procedures and Policies: Practicing the Passive Voice (English Language Proficiency)
event_description: Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. In academic settings, the passive voice is often used to explain procedures, report actions, and emphasize outcomes rather than agents. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice the passive voice in realistic teaching scenarios, such as clarifying policies and describing classroom and laboratory processes. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to ...1. Identify common teaching contexts in which the passive voice is preferred for clarity, formality, or focus.2. Accurately produce the passive voice when explaining procedures, policies, and processes.

event_title: Using Generative AI as a Tool to Align Course Learning Outcomes
event_description: This workshop highlights the importance of aligning course learning outcomes with content and demonstrates how generative AI tools can support this process.Participants will review the purpose of learning outcomes, evaluate alignment strategies, and explore practical ways to use generative AI to enhance alignment. Participants are encouraged to bring a syllabus to use during the session. This workshop will be offered once again on Monday, November 17.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Describe the purpose of course learning outcomes.2) Evaluate the alignment of learning outcomes with course content.3) Use generative AI tools to align learning outcomes with course content.
Be among the first 10 to RSVP and enjoy a free drink on us! Don't miss out on the chance to join us for First Gen and Frappes.

What’s better than sipping on your favorite drink while connecting with others? Counselor Connect: Coffee Edition aims to create a safe space for students to engage with counselors and learn tips on managing their mental health in a cozy cafe environment. Get a taste of how counseling works through 15-minute informal sessions.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Learning How to Learn: Preparing Students to be More Effective Learners
event_description: While academic advisors are fiercely committed to promoting academic success for all students, many have never received instruction in evidence-based learning strategies. Join us to learn about a campus-wide initiative to support student learning focused on the Three Ms for Effective Learning - mindset, metacognition, and memory - concepts distilled from decades of research in cognitive science. Attendees will learn about empirically supported strategies that they can utilize to promote students' academic success. Attendees will also learn how about the various ways in which academic advisors have woven the Three Ms into distinct components of student success advising. Attendees will leave this session with actionable resources to share on their campus with students and colleagues.

event_title: Connecting Classrooms and Communities: An Introduction to Community-Engaged Learning
event_description: Join us for an engaging interactive session designed to introduce faculty to the transformative practices of community-engaged learning.As our institution launches a new initiative focused on service and citizenship, this workshop will explore how instructional approaches that integrate civic engagement, community involvement, academic performance, and professional skills can enrich the undergraduate educational experience. Participants will gain an insightful overview of these practices, discover practical strategies for incorporating them into their course design, and learn how to enhance student engagement and success. Whether you're new to these concepts or looking to innovate your teaching methods, this session offers valuable insights and tools to make a lasting impact on your students' learning journey.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Describe community-engaged learning and how it can support student aca

Regardless of your teaching responsibilities, getting organized early in the semester can save time and reduce stress later on. This session will give you an understanding of Canvas and how to navigate its feature. We’ll also help you set up you gradebook to simplify your teaching and lead to a more efficient and effective semester.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Identify key features of the Canvas interface relevant to your teaching role.2. Explain the purpose and function of basic Canvas tools such as Modules, Assignments, and Announcements.3. Set up basic components of a Canvas course site (e.g., homepage, syllabus, gradebook) based on your specific responsibilities.

event_title: From Clicks to Credits: Leveraging Poll Everywhere for Graded and Formative Assessment
event_description: This hands-on session explores how to use Poll Everywhere not just for engagement, but as a structured tool for graded activities and formal formative assessments. Instructors will learn how to design, deliver, and track student responses to support learning outcomes and instructional decisions.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Create graded polls and quizzes in Poll Everywhere aligned with learning outcomes.2) Interpret activities report for improving formative assessment.3) Using Poll Everywhere LTI and course management feature.

event_title: ELP Journal Club: A Conversation Circle for Text-Based Discussions
event_description: Journal Club is designed for international TAs and faculty to gain confidence in reading aloud and leading and participating in classroom discussions about texts. Each week, participants will receive a short article two days ahead of time to prepare for our discussions. This workshop will focus on improving pronunciation, expanding vocabulary, and developing effective discussion strategies. Participants will also have the opportunity to lead discussions, enhancing their confidence and skills in academic settings.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Read aloud with comprehensible pronunciation and increased confidence.2. Use key terms from academic texts accurately in discussions.3. Effectively facilitate group discussions about various texts.4. Employ turn-taking skills when participating in discussions.
