event_title: University Writing Center Graduate Writing Workshop: Improving Your Flow
event_description: Join the University Writing Center for our Graduate Writing Workshop, "Improving Your Flow," where we’ll discuss what effective flow in writing is and how you can achieve it. After our workshop you'll be able to: Recognize the importance of flow in writing consider audience needs & expectations, identify linguistic strategies for linking & transitioning, and learn to improve the flow of your writing with those strategies. Once you register for the event, you'll receive an email from ERS confirming your registration; then, two days before the event, you'll receive an email from Lauren McAuliffe (lmcauliffe@tamu.edu) to remind you of the event and provide you with the zoom link. We're excited to see you there!

event_title: ELP Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 5): Prominent Words and Discourse Cues
event_description: Fifth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop teaches the intonation that speakers need in order to convey their intended message, with well-placed emphasis. Discourse cues (transition signals) are introduced as tools that help the audience follow the speaker's logic.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1.Distinguish content words (meaningful words) from function words (grammatical words).2.Pronounce the prominent word within a phrase with the appropriate pitch, volume, length, and vowel quality.

event_title: (Virtual) Engage Your Students Better Using Canvas Course Analytics
event_description: Discover how to make the most of Canvas Course Analytics to boost student engagement and success.This session introduces the key features of Course Analytics (formerly New Analytics) and demonstrates how instructors can use data to understand student participation, identify at-risk learners, and tailor course strategies for improved outcomes. Whether you're new to analytics or looking to deepen your insights, this workshop will equip you with practical tools to enhance your teaching and support student learning.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Interpret key metrics in Canvas Course Analytics to monitor student participation, assignment submissions, and overall engagement trends.2) Use data insights from Course Analytics to make informed decisions that support student success and improve instructional strategies.3) Utilize Canvas tools to address student disengagement, including setting up alerts

event_title: (In-Person) Engage Your Students Better Using Canvas Course Analytics
event_description: Discover how to make the most of Canvas Course Analytics to boost student engagement and success.This session introduces the key features of Course Analytics (formerly New Analytics) and demonstrates how instructors can use data to understand student participation, identify at-risk learners, and tailor course strategies for improved outcomes. Whether you're new to analytics or looking to deepen your insights, this workshop will equip you with practical tools to enhance your teaching and support student learning.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Interpret key metrics in Canvas Course Analytics to monitor student participation, assignment submissions, and overall engagement trends.2) Use data insights from Course Analytics to make informed decisions that support student success and improve instructional strategies.3) Utilize Canvas tools to address student disengagement, including setting up alerts

event_title: Course Makeover Lab: Infusing High-Impact Teaching Practices
event_description: This fast-paced, hands-on lab invites faculty to reimagine a course or assignment by integrating high-impact teaching practices such as service learning, undergraduate research, or collaborative projects. Working individually or in interdisciplinary teams, participants will rapidly prototype course elements, receive peer feedback, and pitch their redesigned ideas in a supportive, creative environment.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Apply community-engaged learning principles, frameworks, and best practices to academic course design

This four-session pronunciation workshop systematically explores the vocal tract and segments of speech that make meaningful differences in North American English. Through a variety of activities and handouts, attendees will become familiar with each consonant sound and with resources to practice listening discrimination and accurate pronunciation on their own. They each have the opportunity to get personalized feedback on their own pronunciation. This event is restricted to those who attended Part 1 (register for that at https://ers.tamu.edu/event/10677).

event_title: GSPDT: How to Motivate Students in the Classroom
event_description: During the middle of the semester, motivation in the classroom can hit a lull. Explore evidence-based techniques to foster student motivation in the college classroom. By the end of this session, you will be able to create engaging, inclusive, and purposeful learning environments that promote student persistence and success in your classroom.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Recognize common barriers to student motivation in the college classroom.2. Differentiate between effective and ineffective motivational practices.3. Implement classroom strategies that enhance student engagement and motivation. 4. Construct a classroom plan that incorporates targeted motivation strategies.

ALL ARE WELCOME!!!!! Bring your laptop and leave with an upgraded resume.
Take a mid-semester break with a free late-night breakfast! Enjoy karaoke, a Press Your Luck, cozy PJs, and plenty of fun to reset and recharge.

With over 200 majors and minors, there are great options for your education. Talk to college representatives at the Majors & Minors Fair to explore all the opportunities Texas A&M has to offer. This is a casual dress event and students can come and go during the event. Join us to explore and Discover Direction!

event_title: Gen AI Foundations Workshop for Intermediate
event_description: Some Prior Knowledge Required This intermediate workshop is designed for faculty/staff with a technical background who are interested in deepening their understanding of Generative AI (GenAI) and its applications. Participants will explore the distinctions between GenAI and traditional AI, critically evaluate popular tools, and analyze their strengths and limitations. Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to… 1) Differentiate Generative AI (GenAI) from traditional AI approaches by analyzing underlying architectures and learning paradigms (e.g., transformers vs. rule-based systems). 2) Evaluate commonly used GenAI tools (e.g., ChatGPT, DALL·E, Copilot) and assess their suitability for specific tasks. 3) Analyze the strengths and limitations of GenAI, including technical challenges such as hallucinations, bias, and model interpretability. 4) Implement no-code GenAI tools to automate or augment tasks such as summarization, image generation, and data transformation, wit

Unleash your creativity and groove to the beat at our Paint and Jam event! Whether you're a seasoned artist or a first-timer, this is your chance to express yourself through art while enjoying great music and good company. Grab a paintbrush and let the rhythm move you as you create a masterpiece. It's all about having fun, letting go, and embracing the creative process in a relaxed, vibrant atmosphere. Join us for a night of painting, jamming, and connecting—because creativity is better with good tunes and great friends! We will be serving Chic-Fil-A nuggets and mac and cheese

event_title: How to Use Navigate360 Communication Tools
event_description: This session will cover To-Dos, Emails, Messaging Campaigns, and Appointment Campaigns.

event_title: ELP Practice Group for Instructors Fall 2025 (Session 6): Asking Questions and Active Learning
event_description: Sixth in a series of workshops for international graduate students, faculty, post-docs, and visiting scholars. This interactive workshop introduces Bloom's Taxonomy and the "flipped classroom" approach where active learning takes place during class time. It encourages teachers to ask their students thought-provoking questions that are grammatically correct and pronounced with correct intonation.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1.Distinguish lower-order thinking from higher-order thinking.2.Generate questions appropriate for college students.3.Pronounce wh- questions and yes/no questions with accurate grammar and appropriate intonation contours.

Howdy! The Department of Economics is hosting a financial literacy workshop for undergraduate and graduate students! We'll include topics & resources related to: • How to have healthy financial habits early • The Path to Financial Well-Being • The Financial Planning Process as a student • Resources (websites, podcasts, apps, etc.) you can refer to There will be two options for this RSVP: 1. Lunch before the presentation 2. Just the presentation Lunch will be from 11:30 AM-12:00 PM in the WCSS Advising Suite and lobby. The presentation will take place from 12:00 PM-12:45 PM in the WCSS 144.

event_title: GSPDT: How to Plan a Teaching Demonstration
event_description: In this workshop, we will get into the concept of teaching demonstration and learn how to design it based on the course design cycle. Participants will be able to plan their own teaching demonstration by the end of this session.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Define the purpose of a teaching demonstration.2. Explain how the course design cycle can guide the planning of a teaching demonstration.3. Give examples of strategies that will set a teaching demonstration apart from others.4. Develop a teaching demonstration plan.

event_title: Hear from Peers: There's no "U" in AI: A writing center perspective on writing with generative AI
event_description: How the writing center can help students see the uses and limitations of GenAI as a writing tool.

Unleash your inner architect with Counselor Connect: Build Edition! Students will get the opportunity to discuss mental health and self-care practices while building Lego creations. Get a feel for counseling through a laid-back environment while having meaningful conversations with our counselors.

This session provides a brief overview of Testing Services’ English Language Proficiency Exam (ELPE), including information about the test format and scoring. It also offers some tips for success, information about additional professional development events, and an opportunity to ask any questions that attendees may have.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to...1. Distinguish the three TAMU offices related to English Language Proficiency.2. Identify strengths and weaknesses in a teaching demonstration.

The recent Title II revision (the Final Rule) mandates that all digital content meet accessibility standards, ensuring usability for all users. This last session of the Digital Accessibility Series focuses on leveraging accessibility tools found in Canvas. Discover how to effectively use Canvas’s built-in accessibility checker to identify and address accessibility issues within your course materials. Learn to interpret the Ally report, apply its recommendations, and improve the overall accessibility of your content.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1. Identify how to navigate and utilize Canvas’s built-in accessibility checker effectively.2. Analyze and interpret accessibility reports generated by Ally.3. Apply recommendations from Canvas and Ally to improve the accessibility of course materials.

Ever wondered what your professors are like outside of the classroom? "Dinner with a Prof" is your chance to sit down with a faculty member over a relaxed meal, hear their personal story, and learn about what they’re passionate about. Each month, a different professor will share their experiences, offer advice, and talk about topics they care deeply about. It's a great opportunity to ask questions, get to know your professors as real people, and build connections that could last long after graduation. We’ve got you covered—dinner is on us, and we’ll take care of all the details, including any dietary restrictions. You just show up and enjoy the conversation! Keep an eye out for the theme of each dinner, and don’t miss out on this chance to make valuable connections in a low-pressure, fun environment. We hope to see you there!

Welcome to Navigate360. This session will give an overview of Navigate360 and cover the Staff Home, setting appointment availability, calendar syncing, reporting on appointments, and the Student Profile. This session is also great as a refresher for Navigate360. *Must have staff-level access in Navigate360 to participate in session. This session will be held through Zoom.

event_title: Course Organization Series (Part 1): Mastering Canvas Modules
event_description: Kick start this semester with us as we explore the significance of structured course content and discover strategies for maintaining consistency and accessibility in your Canvas modules. Enhance your course management skills with practical tips and best practices!Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1)Discuss the importance of organizing course content utilizing Canvas Modules.2) Identify ways to organize course content by ensuring consistency and accessibility.

event_title: Conversation and Canes: Domestic Violence Awareness
event_description: October 15, 2025 | 5–7 PM | Commons 109 Join us for Conversation and Canes: Domestic Violence Awareness as we shine a light on the realities of domestic violence, share resources, and foster healing through dialogue. Special guest speaker Jon Hill will offer insight, inspiration, and a call to action. Whether you’re here to listen, learn, support, or stand in solidarity—ALL ARE WELCOME. Show your support by wearing purple!! Let’s build a safer, more informed community together.

event_title: Academy for Future Faculty - Integrating Accessibility
event_description: Dr. Kristie Orr, Director of Disability Resources, and Justin Romack, Assistant Director for Assistive Technology Services, will lead this session on creating inclusive and accessible learning environments. Drawing from their extensive experience supporting students and educators, they will share practical strategies to ensure equitable access to the classroom for all learners. Participants will leave with a deeper understanding of accessibility in higher education and tools they can apply to promote student success across diverse learning needs.Participants will be able to:1. Define key principles of accessibility in higher education.2. Apply practical strategies to make teaching and course design more inclusive.3. Evaluate their own classroom practices for opportunities to improve accessibility.

event_title: Don’t Tense Up about Verb Tenses: Choosing the Right Tense to Communicate Effectively (English Langu
event_description: Grammatical errors can hinder successful spoken communication. Speakers can communicate more effectively when they utilize the appropriate verb tense. In this workshop, attendees will review and practice narrative verb tenses while discussing research and reviewing previously covered classroom topics. They’ll explore the pedagogical impact of reviewing prior learning. An optional assignment for extended practice will be available on Canvas.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1.Utilize narrative tenses to recall previous lecture material and discuss connections to current content.2.Produce narrative verb tenses effectively in the discussion of research findings, choosing the appropriate tense to convey temporal relationships.3.Facilitate review activities during lab sessions or lectures, utilizing appropriate narrative tenses to reiterate and reinforce key concepts covered in previous classes.

event_title: Canvas Organization Series (Part 2) : Tips and Strategies from the Instructor’s Point of View
event_description: Designed specifically for faculty, this session offers practical strategies to organize your Canvas course in ways that mirror how you teach and think about your content. Using customized templates, you’ll create a clear and consistent course layout. We’ll also focus on improving student navigation and ensuring your course meets accessibility standards, helping your students engage easily and confidently with your materials.Learning Outcomes:Participants will be able to…1) Implement customized templates to create a consistent and logical structure for organizing course content like the syllabus, resources, and assignments.2) Review and revise current Canvas course page to ensure clear navigation for students.3) Assess accessibility standards for course materials and layouts

event_title: Gen AI Foundations Workshop for Beginners
event_description: No Prior Knowledge Required This workshop is intended for faculty and staff with no prior experience in AI and limited technical background. Participants will get an introduction to AI principles, the strengths and limitations of GenAI tools, and using No-Code tools and methods to leverage AI. Learning Outcomes: Participants will be able to… 1) Define Generative AI (GenAI) and distinguish it from traditional AI approaches. 2) Identify commonly used GenAI tools (e.g., ChatGPT, DALL·E, Copilot) and describe their practical applications in everyday tasks. 3) Explain the basic strengths and limitations of GenAI, including issues like hallucinations and bias. 4) Recognize key ethical considerations and discuss principles for responsible use of GenAI in educational contexts. 5) Demonstrate how to use no-code GenAI tools to complete simple tasks such as summarizing text or generating images. 6) Apply basic prompt engineering techniques to improve the quality and relevance of Ge

event_title: GSPDT: AI Tools to Help Boost Classroom Engagement
event_description: Discover how to use Generative AI tools to boost classroom engagement. This hands-on workshop will equip you with practical skills to create dynamic and interactive learning experiences. event_title: Brains Behind the Chatbots: How Transformers Power Large Language Models
event_description: Chatbots like ChatGPT may seem magical, but what’s really going on inside their “brains”? The answer is Transformers—a breakthrough in artificial intelligence. Unlike older models that read words one at a time, transformers look at an entire sentence (or even a whole paragraph) at once, figuring out how each word relates to the others. This “attention” trick allows large language models (LLMs) to generate smooth, meaningful text, translate languages, and even hold conversations that feel natural. In this talk, we’ll break down the magic behind transformers using simple examples, explore how models learn from huge amounts of data, and play with the “settings” that shape their personality—like temperature (how creative the AI sounds) and top-k (how many word options it considers). By the end, you’ll understand not only how these models work, but also why they’re changing the way we study, work, and create.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Advising Students Through the Door of Return Toward Transformational Global Learning
event_description: This engaging webinar offers academic advisors' practical strategies to explore student-centered advising techniques to prepare and support students' engagement in cross-cultural, high-impact learning experiences such as international service-learning trips. Grounded in the frameworks of Minority Identity Development and Holistic Advising Redesign, this session will examine how these concepts intersect with equity in advising to support the whole student, not just academically, but socially, emotionally, and culturally. Emphasis will be given to advising strategies that recognize the relative importance of intentional integration of high-impact practices (HIPs), such as study abroad, service learning, and undergraduate research; highlighting the transformative potential of these experiences, especially when introduced early to Black, Latinx, Indigenous, Asian, Pacific Islander, and Pell grant students. event_description: A strong score on the ELPE can make an international graduate student eligible to be hired as a TA. Those who attend this workshop have the opportunity to attend ELPE Presentation Practice (Microteaching) with feedback from experienced TAs, shortly after this event. For more details, see https://ers.tamu.edu/event/7101

Whether you’re feeling jolly or just want to chill before finals, this is the place to be. Prizes for the best (worst?) sweaters! ALL ARE WELCOME!!!!! Bring your holiday cheer (or just your friends)!

Undergraduate Research staff, along with the Undergraduate Research Ambassadors, will go over expectations, strategies for finding faculty mentors, and resources available to help you get started in research. Current undergraduate research students will describe their experiences and provide advice on the most effective strategies for getting started.

event_title: ECON Change of Major Info Session
event_description: Interested in changing majors to Economics or just wanting to learn more about this major? We are excited to host this information session for all TAMU/Blinn TEAM Students interested in learning about the TAMU ECON Degree, our Change of Major Requirements, and additional opportunities in the Department. Attending a session is not a requirement for students wanting to apply to Change Majors to Economics - this is simply an opportunity to learn more about what our Department offers and ask the ECON Advisors any questions you might have.

event_title: [UGR] Undergraduate Research Scholars POWER Writing Productivity Session
event_description: For students in the Undergraduate Research Scholars thesis program. How do you begin to write your thesis? How do you increase the efficiency and productivity of your writing? This workshop will give you tips and tricks to gain mastery over your writing and help you become a more productive writer and researcher.

event_title: Hear from Peers: Save Time on Prep: Create Ancillaries with AI and OER
event_description: Have you been curious about using AI-created ancillaries? In this session, we will discuss creating AI-powered ancillaries with open educational resources to save time and effort in your course preparation.

This webinar series invites faculty members from diverse disciplines to come together and explore the multifaceted landscape of generative AI. Through a series of engaging discussions and presentations, we will explore themes such as AI literacy and informed decision making, guidelines and policy for integrating AI in the classroom, responsibility and boundaries of AI-generated content, and ethics.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Supporting Students Through a Trauma-Informed Lens
event_description: More students are arriving on campus with experiences of trauma that shape how they learn, engage, and seek support. Academic advisors are often among the first professionals to build trust. This webinar will introduce foundational principles of trauma-informed advising, equipping you with practical strategies to recognize signs of trauma, respond with empathy, and help students connect to resources if needed. Presenters Kaiti Blackburn (Jana's Campaign) and Shantalea Johns (Wayne State University) will draw on research and their lived experiences to discuss how trauma can impact a student's brain, behavior, motivation, and academic performance. You'll learn how to create safer advising spaces, support students through challenges, and make intentional choices that foster dignity and belonging, without overstepping your role or taking on more than is sustainable.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Small Changes, Big Impact: Creating Institutional Structure to Support New Advisor D
event_description: The process of training as a new advisor can often be a trial by fire. Advising offices can create practices and resources that give structure and support to the learning process for new advisors, and NACADA’s Core Competencies and New Advisor Development Chart provide a map of what should be learned. Yet the process of creating comprehensive training and development programs from the ground up can feel daunting (if not impossible). This webinar’s hosts will share their experiences creating structures to support new advisor learning and break down their developments into manageable steps for implementation. We will help you dream big in design and think small in implementation to see your interventions compound changes over time (and will include a few helpful resources to get started with those small changes).

event_title: [UGR] Undergraduate Research Scholars Writing Abstracts Workshop
event_description: Want to publish your research? A great abstract is not only a requirement for the Undergraduate Research Scholars program, but it is also serves as the “resume” for your research to outside viewers and prospective publishers. Because writing an abstract is an unfamiliar process for those who are new to research, we want to teach you the basics. Visit https://uwc.tamu.edu for more information and help on writing abstracts.

event_title: [UGR] Undergraduate Research Scholars Presentation Skills Workshop
event_description: At this workshop, you will learn the DOs and DON’Ts of giving a presentation. We will give you tips about the best way to present a poster, as well as instruct you on how to effectively use a PowerPoint presentation. Because a public presentation of your research is a requirement of the URS thesis program, we highly recommend this workshop as a helpful resource. Visit https://uwc.tamu.edu for more information on giving effective presentations. Visit https://tx.ag/URSthesis to learn more about the Undergraduate Research Scholars thesis program.

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Please Won't You Be My Advisor?
event_description: Fred Rogers, writer, producer, and actor for the infamous public television show Mr. Roger's Neighborhood, believed that the kindness and support of 'just one person' could help a child to reach their full potential. As advisors, most of us entered this helping profession with exactly that in mind-the hope that we can cheerlead alongside our students to help them to build the pathways and successes to support their greatest goals. In this episode, listeners will 'ride along through the neighborhood' and learn about Fred Rogers' theory of personal development and its applications to academic advising. We will examine the 'just one person' model and its potential influences for specialized and underrecognized populations of students, including refugee students. Second, we will apply Mr. Roger's four 'simple interactions approach,' which includes the basic interaction strategies of creating connection, inclusion, reciprocity, and opportunity for growth. Finally, we will explore how adviso

event_title: NACADA Webinar: Reset for College Success: From Suspension to Graduation
event_description: Is your institution looking for a fresh, new way to support probation and reinstated students? At our institution, we have created a course designed to empower students by developing skill sets geared toward academic, personal and professional success. This presentation is led by two knowledgeable instructors who have a combined 8 semesters of course instruction. Topics featured are course design, weekly course topics, assignments, how we provide support throughout the semester and data to back up our findings over the 5 years of the Suspension Waiver Program.

Interested in writing an undergraduate thesis? Undergraduate Research staff will explain the details, opportunities, and eligibility requirements for the Undergraduate Research Scholars thesis program. As long as you are an undergraduate, this program is open to all majors. Faculty research advisors are encouraged to attend with undergraduates. More information about the program can be found at https://tx.ag/URSthesis Published Undergraduate Theses can be found in our OAKTrust Collection at https://oaktrust.library.tamu.edu/handle/1969.1/3367.

Artificial Intelligence is rapidly reshaping the landscape of higher education, from how students access information to how institutions provide support. But what does this mean for academic advisors? In this timely and practical session, Jeff Elliott (Purdue University) and Mitch Colver (American Public University System) will explore how AI tools can be integrated into advising workflows in meaningful, ethical ways. The session will address real-world use cases, such as drafting outreach messages, organizing notes, and managing repetitive tasks, while also tackling key questions around data privacy, professional judgment, and student trust. Whether you're cautiously curious or actively experimenting with AI, this conversation will help you move forward with confidence.
